B00005JOVH|3.0|The first X-Men movie was, in my opinion, not a fantastic movie at all.  I'm no comic book junkie, but I'm a movie lover.  So of course, my expectations of X-Men weren't really balanced when I went to see the first movie.  It disappointed overall, and so I thought X2 would be just as bad.  To my surprise, X2 was astounding.  Perhaps one of the best Superhero movies ever made.  It had action, characterization, and overall good plot and story.  Even people who aren't X-Men fans could get into X2.  X2 still ranks as one of the finest comic book adaptations out there.<br /><br />Now we get to X-Men: The Last Stand.  Brett Ratner directed this one, and I won't say he did a terrible job.  I will say however, that The Last Stand doesn't hold a candle to X2: X-Men United. Let us clear up one little misunderstanding: This is not the last X-Men movie.  People will think so because it's called \\"The Last Stand\\" but it isn't the last in the movie franchise (which may be why they put that little extra after the credits).<br /><br />There is now a \\"cure\\" for the mutant gene.  Mutants have a choice as to whether or not they can take this cure.  Some mutants are thrilled by the chance to finally be \\"normal\\" others are outraged and crying out that there doesn't need to be a cure at all.  Even worse, the government has been manufactoring the cure into a weapon without saying anything to the nation.  And when Magneto finds out, all hell breaks loose.  Unless the government eradicates \\"the cure\\" Magneto promises a war.  And he delivers.<br /><br />But Magneto's war isn't the only thing going on in this film.  Cyclops is mourning Jean's death, but later comes to discover that Jean isn't dead.  In more revelations, Xavier admits that Jean is the most powerful mutant out there.  Except now Jean can't control her powers.  Her powers seem to control her.  The X-Men now have two problems on their hand.  A war that's about to break out, and dealing with class five mutant that's more powerful than anyone could possibly imagine.  And as Magneto's war carries on, the two problems soon merge into one massive disaster.<br /><br />It's hard to talk about the movie without providing a few spoilers.  New faces come on board for the newest installment of the franchise, but at the same time, a few have left.  For example: Nighcrawler isn't in the movie at all, and they don't even bother to explain where he went.  He's just gone. The new characters that come about though, are not in huge numbers.  Most of them join up with Magneto.<br /><br />When it comes to the characters in this film, however, there are a few things that urk me.  Old characters are changed.  We all know Wolverine used to be a tough guy who went at everything his own way.  He maintains going at things his own way, but his persona seems to have changed.  He's not ruthless and willing to stand at fight the way he used to.  It's a little distracting, considering what he went through to save those he cared about in the second movie.  Even worse, old characters get nothing to enhance the development started in the previous two films.  The new characters that come about get no development at all.  This is unforgiveable to those who enjoyed the character driven story of the second movie.  Here, it seems to be about the incredible special effects rather than the characters.  There's a lot of emphasis on what goes on around the characters rather than what's actually happening to them, and that's sad to admit.<br /><br />The characters don't just suffer in terms of development, they suffer in terms of acting as well.  The characters who returned to reprise their roles do a fairly good job.  Hugh Jackman and Patrick Stewart are fantastic.  However, the real talent lies in Ian McKellen.  Single handedly, he carries to movie from start to finish.  It's amazing the man doesn't have an oscar yet, as whenever he's in a role, you look at him not as an actor, but as the character.<br /><br />However, as I said, the new actors who came on board are weak.  They act as though they have no direction.  Which brings me to the script.  A lot of the dialogue is corny and tacky.  When delivered from the cast that joins the X-Men roster, they even sound as though they were unsure of the script.  It's as if the director didn't care to work with them enough.  A lot of the new characters aren't really into character at all.<br /><br />The special effects are dazzling, though.  They look fantastic and play out extremely well.  Again, however, too much emphasis is put on the special effects.  There's little emphasis at all on the characters however.  It's hard to feel for the new characters introduced.<br /><br />The bottom line is simple: If you're a movie goer that loves a character driven story where you actually grow to shake hands with the characters and feel for them... this movie is simply not for you.  It clearly has summer blockbuster written all over it.  There are plenty of special effects and explosions, but hardly any substance beyond that.  Even the storyline feels a bit like an extra at times.  The war is given perfect emphasis, but we don't really go back and explore Jean that much.  It's to the point where you really don't care that she's become someone controlled by her own powers.  We don't learn enough about her dark side anyway.<br /><br />However, if you're one who loves to go to a movie just for the sake of having fun, I'd be lying to you if I told you you weren't going to find it here.  The movie is a fun ride.  The special effects are brilliant, and there's a comedic essence to the movie that makes it enjoyable to watch, despite some of the bad dialogue.  The final scenes of the movie are among the best.<br /><br />Overall, it's 3.5.  It's definitely a summer movie.  Lots of fun and excitement, but with little substance, and that's hard to admit seeing as how other super hero movies such as X2, Spider Man 2 and Batman Begins were willing to take that extra step that made you see them as more than just summer hits, but rather as actual films of acheivement.  X-Men: The Last Stand is a good movie, but doesn't take that extra leap that other superhero movies before it took.r />However, as I said, the new actors who came on board are weak.  They act as though they have no direction.  Which brings me to the script.  A lot of the dialogue is corny and tacky.  When delivered from the cast that joins the X-Men roster, they even sound as though they were unsure of the script.  It's as if the director didn't care to work with them enough.  A lot of the new characters aren't really into character at all.  <br /> <br />The special effects are dazzling, though.  They look fantastic and play out extremely well.  Again, however, too much emphasis is put on the special effects.  There's little emphasis at all on the characters however.  It's hard to feel for the new characters introduced.   <br /> <br />The bottom line is simple: If you're a movie goer that loves a character driven story where you actually grow to shake hands with the characters and feel for them... this movie is simply not for you.  It clearly has summer blockbuster written all over it.  There are plenty of special effects and explosions, but hardly any substance beyond that.  Even the storyline feels a bit like an extra at times.  The war is given perfect emphasis, but we don't really go back and explore Jean that much.  It's to the point where you really don't care that she's become someone controlled by her own powers.  We don't learn enough about her dark side anyway.   <br /> <br />However, if you're one who loves to go to a movie just for the sake of having fun, I'd be lying to you if I told you you weren't going to find it here.  The movie is a fun ride.  The special effects are brilliant, and there's a comedic essence to the movie that makes it enjoyable to watch, despite some of the bad dialogue.  The final scenes of the movie are among the best.   <br /> <br />Overall, it's 3.5.  It's definitely a summer movie.  Lots of fun and excitement, but with little substance, and that's hard to admit seeing as how other super hero movies such as X2, Spider Man 2 and Batman Beginswere willing to take that extra step that made you see them as more than just summer hits, but rather as actual films of acheivement.  X-Men: The Last Stand is a good movie, but doesn't take that extra leap that other superhero movies before it took.

B000E1ZBGS|1.0|I was excited to see this condensed version of P&P and relied on friend reviews. Previous to receiving reviews, I had planned not to see this version, because to me the BBC version was definitive. I was extremely sorry to find that this version is noisy, busy, and much less good than the BBC version. The lines of dialogue are chipped out, barely said, you can hardly tell who anyone is, except for Bingley's huge head of hair, and all of the participants seem to be born in a barn. The slamped-t0-the-head hairstyle is old now and particularly unwelcome in the Georgian period. Further, Donald Sutherland fails to convince as Mr. Bennett. The whole thing struck me initially as horrid and a waste of time, upon viewing it again, scene by scene, I still think it lesser than the BBC version, but liked it better. However, if you are interested in Pride and Prejudice, watch the full BBC version with Colin Firth and Jennifer Ehle first.<br /><br />Further, this version has none of the beauty or satisfaction of the original BBC version, plus, the screenplay takes huge advantage and abuses the story. So enjoy the barnyard version of P&P. There are beauties in this version, but not it's not quite as  satisfying as the A&E version.

0790733226|5.0|I'm a huge fan of the writings of Carl Sagan, but I found his foray into fiction only mildly interesting.  Happily, \\"Contact\\" is that rare instance when the movie is better than the book. It is worth the price of the DVD just for the awe-inspiring visuals of the opening sequence. The clever use of media sources for exposition, & the manipulated image of president Clinton (from his \\"Mar's rock\\" speech I believe) make it noteworthy. I also enjoyed the remarks by Ellie's \\"father\\" at the movie's end, as well as her testimony. In my opinion, this is Jodie Foster's finest role. If you're looking for a space alien shoot-em-up get Starship Troopers because this movie will dissapoint you - which may explain why this movie is often overlooked & under-rated. However, if you're in the market for a relevant examination of a \\"first contact\\" scenario, and some commentary on the media, politics, spiritual experience, and faith, then this might work for you.
B000F1IQN2|5.0|4.5 Stars. This is an outstanding movie. After viewing the majority of the most critically acclaimed movies of this year of any genre, this one definitely deserved to be a nominee for \\"Best Picture\\" at the Academy Awards.<br /><br />As a thriller, \\"Munich\\" is efficient, absorbing, effective. As an ethical argument, it is haunting. It opens with a heart-stopping re-enactment of the kidnapping and deaths of Israeli atletes at the 1972 Munich Olympics. While many will remember the feats of athletes such as Soviet gymnast Olga Korbut and U.S. swimmer Mark Spitz (Spitz, an American of Jewish faith, had already won his record 7 gold medals before this tragic event and was advised to leave Germany after being warned that he was an inviting target for further terrorism and agreed with West German officials), others will be painfully haunted by the memory of this horrific act just 6 days before the games were to finish (competition was suspended for 24 hours).<br /><br />Israeli Prime Minister Golda Meir states to her cabinet members \\"Forget peace for now\\". In her office it shows the formation of a secret Israeli revenge squad to kill those responsible. The film's most exciting moments are in the details of assassinations. Although the movie is just short of 3 hours (164 minutes), it will keep you riveted.<br /><br />The same debate is going on right now in America. If it is true that civilizations must sometimes compromise their values, the questions remain: What is the cost, and what is the benefit? Spielberg clearly asks if Israel has risked more than it has gained. The movies questions are not only for Israel but for any nation that believes it must compromise its values to defend them. I'm sure this type of question will be debated for years/decades to come.<br /><br />Note: Critic Roger Ebert gave this movie 4 out of 4 stars. Rolling Stone, 3 of 4 stars.

A young Irish couple with their two daughters move to the neighborhood to try to establish a new life....overshadowed by the loss of their son at five years old. <br /> <br />I find myself drawn in the family, deeply sharing their anguish and triumphs.  One scene had me on the edge of my seat....at a street fair when the father is trying to win an ET doll for his youngest daughter.  I won't tell you the outcome. <br /> <br />The youngest daughter, Ariel, has a spirit about her, a curiosity and charisma which brings caring people into the fold of the family.  She is bold and unafraid, yet she yearns for the love of her father, who is emotionally distant following the death of his son. <br /> <br />The oldest daughter, Kristine, is wise beyond her years.  She successfully camptures life on her camcorder, which she uses constantly, almost a video diary if you will.   <br /> <br />The mother is strong and loves her husband with all her heart.  Her husband has shut her out of his emotionbal life, also, and she struggles to deal with that.  She is the glue which binds her family together. <br /> <br />Their neighbor, the \\"screaming man\\" of the building, is a tormented young artist.  The words on his door say it all \\"KEEP AWAY\\".  I won't give away the plot with his role. <br /> <br />A MUST SEE.....I cried, I stopped for a bit, I cried again.  I couldn't stop crying. B000EHSVQ4|5.0|I'm rating this movie vs the theatrical version.  I thought this movie was much better on the special edition DVD than in the theater.  The theatrical version left too many gaps and questions which the director's cut DVD filled and answered.  Although not historically accurate, it was entertaining as a MOVIE.  If you want to watch a good NON-FICTIONAL documentary on the Crusades, I would recommend the Crusades DVD collection from the History Channel.  If you think this movie is an accurate depiction of the Crusades, there are many books you will find that prove otherwise.      The only thing that terribly bothered me was the way the Knights Templar were depicted.  Like raging, bloodlusting brutes.  In all reality they were warrior-monks that were revered by peasants, knights, kings and popes alike (until they were betrayed by a jealous pope and a bankrupt, envious king).
B0009298XY|3.0|This is a silly but somewhat funny spoof based on that seventies something television series by the same name, which starred Paul Michael Glaser (Starsky) and David Soul (Hutch) in the lead roles. In this film, Ben Stiller plays David Starsky and Owen Wilson plays Ken Hutchinson (Hutch), a pair of cops in the free wheeling, psychedelic haze of the nineteen seventies. Both are viewed as problem children by their superior officer and, consequently, are teamed up as partners. The film is really about how Starsky and Hutch met and became partners, something the television series never addressed.<br /><br />Ben Stiller is his usually wacky self as the straight arrow, by the book Starsky, while Owen Wilson positively shines as the laid back, irrepressible Hutch. Owen Wilson's natural comedic gifts allow him to effortlessly steal every scene in which he is featured. He is positively infectious! Snoop Dogg does a good job of reprising the role of Huggy Bear, the street informant that keeps Starsky and Hutch in the loop in terms of criminal activity afoot. Snoop Dogg infuses the role with a sort of natural cool and is funny in his own way, though not as endearing as the original Huggy Bear was in the television series. Still, he makes the role his own, as do Stiller and Wilson with theirs.<br /><br />The movie has a silly plot involving cocaine dealer/business man Reese Feldman, played by Vince Vaughn, who injects the character with just the right amount of sleaze. It appears that Feldman has just come up with a new cocaine that will fool any drug sniffing canine. It is left up to Starsky and Hutch to stop his nefarious scheme, but not without getting themselves involved in some nutty situations along the way. Look for Justin Bateman in the small role of Friday, Feldman's sidekick. Will Ferrell has a small, but pivotal, role as Big Earl, a guy who has some information that Starsky and Hutch need badly enough to...well, see the film. Carmen Electra, Amy Smart, and Juliette Lewis round out the cast and provide the babe factor.<br /><br />The film is a retro look at the nineteen seventies from its fashions to its music. Look for cameo appearances by Paul Michael Glaser and David Soul. To my surprise, Glaser looks a whole lot better than David Soul, who appears not to have aged well. As to the overall rating of this film, I realize that this film may have limited appeal. Those who liked the Starsky and Hutch television series or who are fans of Ben Stiller and Owen Wilson will probably enjoy this goofy, spoofy, sophomoric little film.wis round out the cast and provide the babe factor.<br /><br />The film is a retro look at the nineteen seventies from its fashions to its music. Look for cameo appearances by Paul Michael Glaser and David Soul. To my surprise, Glaser looks a whole lot better than David Soul, who appears not to have aged well. As to the overall rating of this film, I realize that this film may have limited appeal. Those who liked the Starsky and Hutch television series or who are fans of Ben Stiller and Owen Wilson will probably enjoy this goofy, spoofy, sophomoric little film.
B0009A1AS2|5.0|No question that Octavarium is a good, solid Dream Theater album. One of the best in fact. Yet for the premier progressive rock group in the world, they don't seem to be progressing very far - look through their back catalogue and find all the pre-packaged ingredients for Octavarium (maybe in a different time signature).Dream Theater, having established and mastering modern progressive rock, seem content on broadening its scope, rather than moving the genre in a new direction. <br /> <br />Panic Attack is the pick of the album, an intelligent song relevant to todays politics. Similarly impressive is the atmospheric Sacrificed Sons, a reflection on September 11 that doesn't reek of tosspot patriotism. Walk Beside You is fairly catchy, but don't crank it too loud lest someone hears you listening to it. These Walls is also a highlight, LaBrie's vocals really have matured in the last few years.  <br /> <br />The obligatory super epic monster track, 'Octavarium' reminds me of Pink Floyd for some reason at the start (by start I mean the first 8 minutes). Its all technically impressive, but forgettable. <br /> <br />I was particularly impressed by Jordan Rudess in this album, mainly because of his restraint. His keyboards serve to add depth to the songs, rather than dominate. Not that there's anything wrong with dominating mind you.  <br /> <br />Any fan of progressive rock will buy Octavarium, as they should - just to see how progressive you can be without actually going anywhere.
B00006V9A0|5.0|It's been the better part of ten years since Kurt Cobain killed himself, and the music charts are now in a sorry shape. It's only poetic justice, I would think, that Nirvana would suddenly come back to life to send one last single up the charts to show them all how it's done. Accompanying this last single is this excellent compilation - so excellent, in fact, that all the usual criticism reserved for compilations fails to apply. Even the cover is perfect - \\"Nirvana,\\" no other words need be said, the band's name and reputation speak for themselves.<br /><br />Let's face it: Nirvana's albums weren't perfect. Nevermind, for all the ground it broke, was basically a singles album, and In Utero was a deliberate attempt to shed their audience with ugly production and cacophony. But we forgave them their faults thanks to the freshness of the former and the brutal sonic force of the latter - and, of course, thanks to Kurt Cobain's charming insouciance. This compilation, however, collects all the best parts of both. And when I say \\"best parts,\\" I do mean it. All the mainstays are here - \\"Smells Like Teen Spirit,\\" \\"Come As You Are,\\" \\"Heart-Shaped Box\\" - but so are other songs that one wouldn't have thought likely choices for a compilation - \\"Rape Me\\" and \\"Dumb.\\" Yes, they even included \\"Dumb\\", quite possibly Nirvana's best song ever! \\"About a Girl\\" makes an appearance here too, possibly the result of an attempt to include _something_ from Bleach; I suppose it'd have been better if they had picked the unplugged version, but the unplugged album gets represented here too - the beautiful cover of \\"The Man Who Sold The World\\" is here. There are even a couple of relatively obscure gems off Incesticide - the funny childhood story \\"Sliver\\" and the terrific \\"Been A Son.\\"<br /><br />Then there's the new song - \\"You Know You're Right,\\" apparently the last song the band ever recorded. I don't think it's the best song they ever wrote, but it is in a way very definitive - it combines the loud/soft dynamics of Nevermind with some of the more ear-splitting moments of In Utero in the chorus. Cobain's voice in the verses is amazing - the bitterness and proximity to collapse are almost tangible - but it's the bridge to the chorus, in which he simply roars \\"pain,\\" that's really remarkable. It is moments like these in which one understands why Nirvana's music still reaches so many people - with a roar like that with you, you can go take on the world.<br /><br />His great pop talents aside, Cobain was not exactly the second coming of Keats. He was in many ways a product of, and poisoned by, the atrophied anticulture of the ennui-ridden youth of the postmodern age. However, talent will make itself known in any milieu; what made him stand out was his complete awareness of this, his inability to succumb to it or take it lying down, his resulting sadness and rage, and his remarkable ability to convey his emotions, even if his words weren't always clear. Thus we got moments like the wonderfully vicious \\"Smells Like Teen Spirit,\\" the melancholy \\"Dumb,\\" the resigned \\"All Apologies\\" or that everlasting anthem of all rejected outsiders, \\"Lithium.\\" And by this alone, it could be said that he left the world he railed against in better shape than when he entered it.soft dynamics of Nevermind with some of the more ear-splitting moments of In Utero in the chorus. Cobain's voice in the verses is amazing - the bitterness and proximity to collapse are almost tangible - but it's the bridge to the chorus, in which he simply roars \\"pain,\\" that's really remarkable. It is moments like these in which one understands why Nirvana's music still reaches so many people - with a roar like that with you, you can go take on the world. <br /> <br />His great pop talents aside, Cobain was not exactly the second coming of Keats. He was in many ways a product of, and poisoned by, the atrophied anticulture of the ennui-ridden youth of the postmodern age. However, talent will make itself known in any milieu; what made him stand out was his complete awareness of this, his inability to succumb to it or take it lying down, his resulting sadness and rage, and his remarkable ability to convey his emotions, even if his words weren't always clear. Thus we got moments like the wonderfully vicious \\"Smells Like Teen Spirit,\\" the melancholy \\"Dumb,\\" the resigned \\"All Apologies\\" or that everlasting anthem of all rejected outsiders, \\"Lithium.\\" And by this alone, it could be said that he left the world he railed against in better shape than when he entered it. <br />
B000002UR7|2.0|Let's get one thing straight - Radiohead may be the greatest thing to happen to music since the Beatles.  That said, this is not the album for that reason.  Do not let this album turn you off from Radiohead...beacause it is truly not what they are about.  There is one hint though in where Radiohead will go. B000067CPX|4.0|Even if this release hasn't achieved the success of Californication in US, still remains one of the best moments of Red Hot Chili Peppers<br /><br />For the avid Red Hot Chili Peppers fan, this CD has been eagerly awaited since about 2 weeks after the release of 'Californication'. Perhaps one of the best CDs of the past decade, 'Californication' represented the band's arrival on to the mainstream rock charts, and was able to appeal to a wider audience without upsetting the more traditional fans who grew up on 'Mother's Milk'.<br /><br />The early release of the single 'By The Way' suggested a cross between the hard-hitting riffs of 'Blood, Sugar, Sex, Magik' and the more melodic style of 'Californication'. However, the CD is far from what was expected - tracks 2-6 contain far from subtle drug references and feature a fairly 'trippy' sound, while songs such as 'Can't Stop' and 'Minor Thing' see Anthony Kiedis following Live frontman Ed Kowalczyk in moving towards disjointed rap-like vocals.<br /><br />At the same time there are the soft, touching anthems for our generation that we've come to expect from R.H.C.P. Songs like 'I Could Die For You', 'Dosed' and 'Tear' are powerful, near tear-jerking songs. And, to add a further spice to this unusual combination of tracks, a distinctly Latin influence plays a part in 'Cabron' and the remarkable end to 'Venice Queen'.<br /><br />All in all, this is a genuinely stunning collection of songs which should impress die-hard Chili Peppers fans because it avoids the recent trend in rock music towards catering for the teenie-bopper collective, who swarm from group to group like maggots on faeces.<br /><br />Finally, this is definitely one of those CDs that should not be judged after the first hearing - instead make sure you've run through the entire CD at least 4-5 times so as to get a better feel for the music.

B00000J7JO|5.0|Californication is a simply amazing album by the Red Hot Chili Peppers. They try on many different styles here in this album, and seem to excel at all of them.<br /><br />The opening song on Californication, \\"Around the World\\", is a great funk tune. Many more such songs can be found here, such as \\"Get on top\\". The driving bass of these songs serves as a steady foundation on which John Frusciante lays down an array of memorable guitar riffs. These fun tunes seemingly lay a foundation for the ups and downs of this album.<br /><br />The beauty that the Red Hot Chili Peppers have created in their mellow songs is astounding. They take elements of their funk such as the driving bass and drums and combine it with beautiful choruses and guitar to leave you in awe of their musical genius. The mellow pieces of this album, such as \\"Otherside\\", \\"Scartissue\\", and \\"Californication\\" will remain with you for a long time.<br /><br />Another interesting style is an acoustic Zeppelin-esque tone in \\"Road Trippin'\\". The Red Hot Chili Peppers make this style their own by taking their mellow style tunes and layering it with acoustic guitar and a symphonic backdrop.<br /><br />This was my first Red Hot Chili Peppers Album, but it certainly will not be my last. I definitely reccomend this album to everyone, because what sets this album apart is not that it contains so many different styles, but how the band can seemingly take any style and make it their own.

0553801503|1.0|Maybe this series is getting milked for cash, but it is apparent that this author loves to write.  That is commendable and it does deserve recognition.  However...   <br /> <br />What I mean by the title of this review is that I got the sense throughout reading this novel that George is writing this for himself more so than for his readers.  Remember your class with that instructor who clearly had a true passion for his/her work but just taught over the heads of students?  Read \\"A Feast For Crows\\" and deja vu will smack you upside the head.   <br /> <br />This book expands its universe rather than focusing on any sort of resolution.  The fourth book in a series, however, may be a little late for breaking new storylines wide open.  This book is crammed with filler chapters, which again suggests that the author loves his work too much to consider serious editing to sustain the reader's interest.  For instance...   <br /> <br />Queen Regent Cersei hatches a plot to remove Margaery Tyrell (who?  Oh yeah, her) from queen-to-be while still holding the Highgarden alliance.  Interesting for a chapter?  Definitely.  Interesting over 400 pages?  If you haven't read this yet, does that intrigue you to the point of purchase?  Here is a case where George clearly didn't say to himself, \\"If I was a reader, would I lose sleep over the fate of Margaery Tyrell?\\"  In Brienne's instance, she dukes it out with Biter (who?  Oh yeah, him) near the end of the book.  Here again, did George sit back and ponder, \\"If I was a reader, would I feel satisfied after reading over 100 pages from Brienne's POV to arrive at the conclusion that Biter is a mean guy?\\"  This also sets up poorly for Brienne's POV chapters in next decade's installment--\\"Oh, I wasn't beautiful before, and now look at me!  Maybe I shouldn't have taken up this life...\\" etc.  Boom!  That's probably 30 pages-worth of lamenting right there.  Fun for George, but do you want to read through it?  And jeez, why doesn't George give Samwise the boot?  Perhaps it's because George likes writing from Sam's perspective!  Doesn't he ask himself, \\"Hmmm, despite Sam being the only one to ever slay an Other, would my readers be cool with me dismissing that and going back to the old Sam who get spooked by the sound of his own butt-sneezes?\\" <br /> <br />I could go on with listing examples, but ironically enough, chances are my review would end up being as boring as the very novel I'm knocking.  If you'd like advice from a reader's perspective, read the cliffnotes on this one, buy the next book, and hope that things improve.
0143034901|3.0|Several magazine review blurbs (Elle, NYT Book Review, Orlando Sentinel, Wash. Post) on and inside the book's covers compare The Shadow of the Wind to the writings of Borges.  The comparison is unfair to Borges.  Any similarities are superficial only.  Aside from a story revolving around books, a couple of references to labyrinths, and the Spanish language, there is no resemblance whatsoever.<br /><br />The better comparison is to the movie Animal House.  The Shadow of the Wind should have ended at page 471, at most, when all essential matters have been resolved.  Instead, the book drones on for 16 more pages, which include scenes of a hooker smuggled into a hospice and a where-are-they-now follow-up for almost all of the characters, even the minor ones.<br /><br />The book is too long.  Strangely, Zafon seems aware of this, but he does not do much about it.  In three places, what would be long interviews between Daniel Sempere and other characters are instead summarized by long narratives in italics:  the interview with Molins (pp. 125-129); the interview with Fernando Ramos (pp. 204-215); and the interview with Jacinta (pp. 260-278).  The substitution of these summaries for real dialogue suggests both that Zafon is aware that the reader might be on the brink of snoozing and that Zafon wants not so much to impart relevant plot information through characters as to give the reader the effect of a movie flashback.<br /><br />Weirdly, however, Zafon is inconsistent about the use of summaries and of the italicized portions.  Chapter 5 of the Nuria Monfort narrative, for example, is entirely italicized, which is especially strange since the narrative is supposed to be handwritten.  Even some dialogue in the Nuria narrative, such as that of Sanmarti and Fumero, is italicized; but not all of the dialogue in the Nuria narrative is written that way.  On the other hand, Anacleto's recounting of Federico's arrest and prison assault is not summarized in italics, although that recounting is at least as good a candidate as any of the interviews to be a summary.<br /><br />The book has too many characters.  The book's central concept dictates that there will be some duplication.  That concept, that the events of Daniel's life parallel the events of Julian Carax's life, means that each character in Daniel's life will have a counterpart in Carax's life.  But in the story of Daniel's life itself there is unnecessary duplication.  Daniel's story does not need two comic figures:  Fermin and Federico.  His story especially does not need three love interests:  Clara, Nuria, and Beatriz.  (The translator's father might have had a few remarks about this Triple Goddess motif.)<br /><br />Even in a fantasy the particulars should be plausible in order to sustain the fantasy's temporary believability.  Zafon, however, is too loose and free with his language, descriptions, and plot twists.  Russian dolls are not \\"innumerable\\" (p. 7); they are just numerous.  Revealing that Julian has a female half-sibling and her identity toward the end of the book (p. 377) only lessens sympathy for Julian's loss of the object of his love by making it incestuous.  Daniel is lying down after he is shot (pp. 464-465).  How is he then supposed to have seen both a body thrown from the window on the upper-story, where he is lying, and the actual event of death below (p. 465)?  Each of these lapses hurts the story; each could have been avoided.<br /><br />Plausibility of particulars is especially important with the Nuria narrative because the very existence of the narrative strains credulity.  Here the book fails.  The Nuria narrative is supposed to be handwritten (p. 357), yet it takes up 48 of the book's pages (pp. 359-446).  Are we supposed to believe that Nuria sat in her apartment and scratched out such a long narrative while her Underwood typewriter (p. 165) sat next to her unused?  How would the enormous italicized portions in her narrative, described earlier, be represented in handwriting?  With underlining?  How about all capital letters?  And just how big (and heavy) is the envelope supposed to be that Daniel is hauling around containing all of these handwritten pages?<br /><br />In his typical fashion, Borges would have dispatched with this book's story in 10 pages not by writing the book but instead by imagining that the book exists and then writing a synopsis of it.  That would have been an improvement.  In fact, a two-hour TV movie version would be an improvement.  Zafon seems either to wish he were writing a screenplay or to be giving directions to some future screenwriter adapting the book.  A movie would at least eliminate the distracting subplots and minor characters.  Clara Barcelo and Adrian Neri would be eliminated.  Clara's uncle might make a brief appearance, but only to offer to buy Julian's book from Daniel.  Federico is expendable; by implication, so is Anacleto.<br /><br />Until the movie comes out, read Ficciones.out all capital letters?  And just how big (and heavy) is the envelope supposed to be that Daniel is hauling around containing all of these handwritten pages?      In his typical fashion, Borges would have dispatched with this book's story in 10 pages not by writing the book but instead by imagining that the book exists and then writing a synopsis of it.  That would have been an improvement.  In fact, a two-hour TV movie version would be an improvement.  Zafon seems either to wish he were writing a screenplay or to be giving directions to some future screenwriter adapting the book.  A movie would at least eliminate the distracting subplots and minor characters.  Clara Barcelo and Adrian Neri would be eliminated.  Clara's uncle might make a brief appearance, but only to offer to buy Julian's book from Daniel.  Federico is expendable; by implication, so is Anacleto.    Until the movie comes out, read Ficciones.
B00005JP4U|5.0|It's a bit odd to go into a darkened movie theater--the scene of American escapism for the last one hundred years--to receive such a brisk wake-up call. Still, watching this movie in a theater with hundreds of strangers is, I think, the best way to view it because we are all in this together. <br /> <br />If you've been politically aware in the last 10 years, chances are there isn't any one fact in this movie that you haven't heard before. It is a shocking movie nonetheless, and the shock comes from seeing all those facts marshalled together, presenting a clear-cut case. Here's the inconvenient truth: the earth is getting warmer, that our actions are the reasons why it is getting warmer, and that we must all work together to solve this problem or else it will become a crisis for humanity. <br /> <br />The good news is that there are things we can do now that will hopefully avert or diminish the coming havoc, but the first step is learning about the problem. Even though this film is intercut with scenes that often feel like a Al Gore political ad, it's the best way for most people to learn about this problem. The data is explained in easy-to-digest graphics and examples.  <br /> <br />I urge you to see this movie. Take your parents, take your kids. Let's save ourselves before it's too late.

B000E33VWW|3.0|Capote is a broken, self-absorbed, and narcissistic individual. From the start, we see that he is drunk on his fame and accomplishments, and that he has lost his sense of perspective. The inner termoil that results from this delusion is the basis of the film, Capote -- a character study of an ego that crowds out the life of a tormented soul.  <br /> <br />Hoffman's performance alone is reason enough to watch this movie, but prepare yourself to be pulled down by the weighty subject matter and its deliberate pace.

B00005JMYI|5.0|In the book, there were a lot of subtle details that the author included. They all had a reason. For instance, Vivian and Morgaine, both of fairy ancestry, should be shorter than most people, not taller, as with the movie. Also, the women of Avalon, when riding abroad, wear men's breeches. There's a reason for this. Morgause is not an evil sorceress. Neither is Mordred an evil person. The term Merlin is a title, not a name. The priestesses of Avalon do not dress in gaily colored clothes. The sacred well is actually sacred, and not to be treated like some weathered magical artifact. There are numerous other details, others not so subtle that have either been altered or cut out altogether.  <br /> <br />I agree with a previous poster about how the true victims were the actors and actresses of this movie. The scriptwriter probably had to acquiese to either the producer, director, or studio managmenet. How else could any writer, novice or professional, think to leave out or change some of the most important parts of the story? Nothing worked. Not the love between Igraine and Uther. Not the love between Lancelot and Guenivere. Not Arthur's love for Guinevere and his companions. Not Morgaine's love for Lancelot. Not Viviane's commitment to the Goddess. Not the Merlin's or Raven's devotion. Not the sanctity of the Beltane rites. Not the sacredness of Excalibur, of the Holy Regalia of Avalon. Not even Mordred's inner conflicts. He's not evil, only conflicted. Imagine being the son of the High King and not being acknowledged for it because some priests consider it heresy. Imagine the pain the High priestess of Avalon, the Lady of the Lake, had to endure in order to keep Avalon alive. The \\"solo\\" passage through the mists should have been the culmination and greatest test for any priestess. Lastly, who in their right mind would change the ending to any great book? That is the utmost in presumptuousness.  <br /> <br />I am very dissappointed with this movie. Many points and details in the story have either been changed or altered. I do not blame any of the actors or actresses. They did their best for such a mediocre production. Like the Lord of the Rings, Marion Zimmer Bradley's adaptation of the Arthurian legends should have been broken up into three separate movies, each about three hours long. Maybe then can we all truly enjoy the story of The Mists of Avalon.  <br /> <br />This movie was not The Mists of Avalon. It is a different story altogether. How I wish I hadn't seen this under the pretext of MZB's book. If you truly want to enjoy this story, please read the book instead. This movie may have been made for TNT, but that doesn't excuse it's poor quality. We should never lower our expectations for any story. B000002UAR|1.0|This is bad even by the Beatles standards. Not even Yellow Submarine or Ringo's excellent drumming can save this one I'm afraid. Verdict: avoid.
B000067DNC|5.0|There have over the years been a number of great shows that followed a good first season with a great second one, including THE X-FILES, BUFFY THE VAMPIRE SLAYER, and FARSCAPE.  There are a variety of reasons for this in each case.  With STARGATE, it is the increasingly complex storyline about the relations between various races and cultures with access to stargates.  Season One was basically your stargate-of-the-week format, each week an individual adventure with no real connections with any other episode.  This is the format usually preferred by network executives, since it allows new viewers to join a show without much background.  Serious fans, on the other hand, vastly prefer the complex storylines, where each week's episode does not stand on its own, but is embedded in an ongoing saga, almost like a chapter in a huge novel.  This has been and probably will continue to be an ongoing struggle between the creative talent and the network bureaucracy, though my own hope is that the success of shows like LOST will pave the way for more complex formats.<br /><br />Season Two does not tell a single unified story the way that FARSCAPE or BUFFY THE VAMPIRE SLAYER did, but it does start spinning out a largely political struggle about the five races (only a few that we have met by the end of the season) aligned against the Goa'uld.  The STARGATE story by the end of Season One was still a relatively simple affair; by the end of Season Two it was already sufficiently complex as to make following the details difficult for a newcomer.  But it was not only the season long arc; the individual episodes improved in quality as well as the writers came to know the characters better.  All in all, the improvement in the show from Season One was not unexpected, but it was delightful nonetheless.<br /><br />The only sour note in Season Two was the season finale.  Most shows try to build up to a dramatic season-ending episode that both sums up everything that happened in that season and propels the show into the next one.  The season finale for Season Two of STARGATE has to be one of the lamest ever devised.  Most of the problem is that most of the episode was constructed of segments of previous episodes that were simply replayed.  STAR TREK: THE NEXT GENERATION used this method a few times.  My guess is that the latter show used it as a cheap way of creating a new episode.  If 20 minutes of your air time consisted of clips from old shows, then you had dramatically lowered your operating budget.  I do not know why STARGATE employed this method in the season finale, though perhaps they were over budget and had no choice but to go cheap.  Nonetheless, it was a surprisingly false note in an otherwise marvelous season.<br /><br />As with Season One, the story largely focused on the four members of the Stargate SG-1 team, with all other character functioning as supporting characters.  We are introduced to a number of characters who reappear in subsequent seasons, the most important being General Jacob Carter, Samantha's father.  His importance to the show is cemented in the two-part episode that introduces the Tok'ra, a group rebel Goa'uld opposed to the regular Goa'uld, only entering as symbiotes in willing hosts.  Since Sam's father is dying of cancer and the Tok'ra Selmak's host is dying, he is approached to become a host, since Selmak can cure the cancer.  This is also a wonderful resolution to one of my favorite moments of the season, when Sam's father pulls strings to get her admitted to the NASA space program as a potential astronaut.  Not knowing about her work with the Stargate program, he can't understand why she has no interest in going into outer space.<br /><br />All in all, this is a remarkable season for one of the finest Sci-fi series that television has seen.  Although I've never forgiven the Sci-fi channel for failing to renew FARSCAPE, keeping this fine show alive has at least partially redeemed them in my eyes.and propels the show into the next one.  The season finale for Season Two of STARGATE has to be one of the lamest ever devised.  Most of the problem is that most of the episode was constructed of segments of previous episodes that were simply replayed.  STAR TREK: THE NEXT GENERATION used this method a few times.  My guess is that the latter show used it as a cheap way of creating a new episode.  If 20 minutes of your air time consisted of clips from old shows, then you had dramatically lowered your operating budget.  I do not know why STARGATE employed this method in the season finale, though perhaps they were over budget and had no choice but to go cheap.  Nonetheless, it was a surprisingly false note in an otherwise marvelous season. <br /> <br />As with Season One, the story largely focused on the four members of the Stargate SG-1 team, with all other character functioning as supporting characters.  We are introduced to a number of characters who reappear in subsequent seasons, the most important being General Jacob Carter, Samantha's father.  His importance to the show is cemented in the two-part episode that introduces the Tok'ra, a group rebel Goa'uld opposed to the regular Goa'uld, only entering as symbiotes in willing hosts.  Since Sam's father is dying of cancer and the Tok'ra Selmak's host is dying, he is approached to become a host, since Selmak can cure the cancer.  This is also a wonderful resolution to one of my favorite moments of the season, when Sam's father pulls strings to get her admitted to the NASA space program as a potential astronaut.  Not knowing about her work with the Stargate program, he can't understand why she has no interest in going into outer space. <br /> <br />All in all, this is a remarkable season for one of the finest Sci-fi series that television has seen.  Although I've never forgiven the Sci-fi channel for failing to renew FARSCAPE, keeping this fine show alive has at least partially redeemed them in my eyes.

B00005JOYA|3.0|This dark film leads to the question: What have you become?  All he could say was 'Hey, it's gonna be okay.\\"  Who are you to judge?  No one can judge \\"angels.\\"  We are judged according to our deeds.  Sounds like a religious movie.  On the contrary, that huge cathedral in Silent Hill, West Virginia, is used to burn sacrifices; a pagan symbol is atop the tower.    Johnny Cash's \\"Ring of Fire\\" was used as a prelude to show how this pagan cult had taken over the ghost town.  It is symbolic of good verses evil.  Nurse Betty was there in her red sweater and red shoes (no, it's not 'The Wizard of Oz,' but symbolism and falsehoods where no one is as he appears is at the forefront in this creepy-crawly film).  It takes faith to restore innocence and purity.  Faith is the only truth.  Perhaps your faith will protect you, perhaps not?    What's your definition of justice?  You didn't tell me everything.  I double-dare the viewer to learn the truth.  Don't believe their lies -- what they had created mushroomed into an inferno. Rose, her adopted mother, couldn't take any more and drove her Jeep to take the child to the scene of these weird dreams.  There, a coal fire burned underground and ashes float like snow.  She told her \\"It's going to be just you and me\\" but when she thought all was hopeless, she wept from desperation.  They found a devil's playground where the ghost women were \\"desperate housewives\\" right out of 'Pajama Game.'    Lonely and scared in this deserted place, they found a bus stop sign on which Neely Avenue took them to the orphanage and school.  Certain forms you just can't control, like the living dead. Hurt, she yells, \\"Get off my back.\\"  They find things tarnished and are too damaged to see anything is alright, as nothing will ever be the same, even in paradise. B00005O5UJ|5.0|Up until \\"Aqualung,\\" Jethro Tull was known for their eclectic music that went from English-folk to blues and jazz-flavored rock. While some of that music occasionally bordered on harder rock, typically Jethro Tull's music was relatively light and mellow. \\"Aqualung\\" pushed Jethro Tull into hard rock in 1971.<br /><br />The album opens with the title track. The opening guitar riffs are immediately recognizable to anyone familiar with classic rock. As the song progresses, Ian Anderson uses reverberation on his vocals. The combination of guitars and drums with Ian's vocals placed this song solidly into some of the hardest rock being created at the time. The lyrics are about an old, homeless man with lecherous thoughts. The lyrics are very descriptive and poetic, intelligently written and executed. While the topic could have delved into a moral tale, the lyrics are descriptive rather than lamenting or accusatory or a social policy.<br /><br />\\"Cross-Eyed Mary\\" follows, a story about a lady of the night (or day, apparently). As in \\"Aqualung,\\" to which this song refers, the guitar riffs drive to a rock beat, along with Ian Anderson's enthusiastic vocals. Again, the lyrics are descriptive rather than judgmental. In an era when many songs exhorted compassion and care, these lyrics observed and described.<br /><br />After the first two harder sounding songs comes \\"Cheap Day Return,\\" a return to the acoustic English folk sound typical of Tull's earlier albums. This short song is almost an interlude between the previous song and \\"Mother Goose.\\" \\"Mother Goose\\" is surrealistic and poetic, mixing references to fictional characters and plays on names. The song is largely acoustic and heavily folk influenced, Ian's flute lending a medieval sound to the music. At one point the vocals also harmonize in a folk-like fashion. Near the end of the song an electric guitar provides occasional accompaniment to provide a slightly harder edge to this folk-sounding piece.<br /><br />Continuing the mellower music is \\"Wond'ring Aloud,\\" with strings and acoustic instruments. The music is folk; the lyrics are mellow and an enjoyment of life. Before we think the album is going to stay in the folk vein for the rest of the album, \\"Up to Me\\" returns to the guitar-laden music of the opening songs. The guitar riffs are recognizable as being from the late 60s/early 70s, but the Ian Anderson lyrics continue to be obscure and poetic.<br /><br />The next five songs together make up \\"My God,\\" a concept within itself that questions religion and the hypocrisy of people that style themselves believers in God. Included are questions regarding buying salvation and the role of religion in war and life, and whether people in the church are as pure and holy as religion would have you believe. Given current events, these lyrics are as relevant today as they were in 1971.<br /><br />\\"My God\\" begins with guitar riffs that may remind you of Black Sabbath. The song is complex, however, and later the vocals are chants that may be intended to invoke an image of monastic chants to the listener. While the lyrics of \\"Aqualung\\" were observatory and descriptive, these lyrics are accusatory, demanding to know why religion isn't living up to its own ideals. The remaining songs of the original album, \\"Hymn 43,\\" \\"Slipstream,\\" \\"Locomotive Breath\\" and \\"Wind-Up,\\" all have a common theme based on religion, questioning the role and morality of organized religion.<br /><br />There are several versions of this album available.  This import from Japan is a remaster with six bonus tracks.  The cost of these various versions varies. The bonus tracks exist on some of the other versions, and their principal value is adding more bulk to the original vinyl album, which was a bit more than 43 minutes long. Be sure you see which version suits your needs the best before buying.<br /><br />This album has two faces, \\"Aqualung\\" and \\"My God.\\" \\"Aqualung\\" is relatively objective observation. \\"My God\\" questions religion. Much of the music is rock, often with a harder edge. The lyrics are inspired, occasionally obscure, often poetic, and always intelligent. If there was a category in rock called intellectual rock, this album would be in it. While this album is unlikely to appeal to many mainstream rock fans, the music and lyrics at the time were avant-garde, keeping in the tradition of Jethro Tull, and thus having substantial progressive rock elements. A must have for fans of cutting edge classic rock music.y God\\" questions religion. Much of the music is rock, often with a harder edge. The lyrics are inspired, occasionally obscure, often poetic, and always intelligent. If there was a category in rock called intellectual rock, this album would be in it. While this album is unlikely to appeal to many mainstream rock fans, the music and lyrics at the time were avant-garde, keeping in the tradition of Jethro Tull, and thus having substantial progressive rock elements. A must have for fans of cutting edge classic rock music.  <br />
B000BB1MI2|3.0|Maybe I loved the original one too much, but this version of the story did not work for me. I especially was dissapointed in the music and the oompa loompas. Stick with the first one. It was perfect!
B000BEZQ18|5.0|This is a very beautiful score that complements a soundtrack where the two main characters are laconic men of the West who speak little, move slowly, and live intensely.  The women in their lives are powerful as well, but also do not always speak a lot. <br /> <br />The scenery is spectacular, and the music reflects it as well as the interplay of the characters as they interact in, within, and against it. <br /> <br />The interval music--\\"Riding Horses,\\" \\"Snow,\\" \\"Brokeback Mountain,\\" and \\"Wings\\" are where Santaolalla excells.  These pieces perfectly encapsulate, permeate, and surround specific dramatic intervals in the film.  Although they are very brief, hearing them immediately brings back images and scenes that were also very skillfully captured visually.  Additionally, the music brings back the emotional reactions of the individual to the characters, the places, and the story as they were in the theatre, seeing and listening to the film. <br /> <br />Fans of country music will enjoy the honky tonk tunes and beautiful ballads.  Although eminently current musically, they are typical music of that time and place and also serve as backdrops and foils for the lives of the various characters as they unfold before us.  Although they were played in the background in the film, as stand alone pieces in the soundtrack their subconscious message becomes very clear.  A love ballad heard when one of the characters is dancing romantically with his wife or girlfriend really expresses what is or should be happening if the two men were actually together.  The songs of love lost are plaintive as only a country song can express.  Again, they are mainly meant for the two men who were never really able to be fully together. <br /> <br />This is a painful story of love that was never able to fully express itself and a society that would have and may have killed one or of both of the men if they had openly tried to live together as a couple.  The larger theme strikes a universal chordalthough this is a story of love thwarted between two men who themselves never really realized that what they felt for each other was truly the love of their lives.  <br /> <br />It is no surprise that this composer won the Oscar for Best Score with this soundtrack.  What is surprising is that Mr. Santaolalla, who is from Argentina, was able to zero in on the musical ethos and pathos of a story, characters, and time so far removed from his own personal experience.  However, as this score is the product of a musical genius, there is probably little room for actual surprise at what he has produced.

B000007T2Z|4.0|Just too erratic and unfocused. It's like the young, little brother of \\"Lift Your Skinny Fists\\" -- there's so much talent and brilliance to be found, but within that overwhelming greatness is a sense of self-indulgence, pretentiousness, and an overall feeling of \\"what are we doing and, if we can ever find that out, can we even pull it off?\\".     Musically the album impresses endlessly, and Godspeed! rarely fails on that account. The problem lies within the album's sense of identity. While much of it is driving or beautiful, it seems much more superficial than their following effort, \\"Slow Riot for New Zero Kanada\\". The last half of \\"Providence\\" is perhaps the most acute example of this -- a roaring melody a la a 'much' subdued male chorus, rhythmic strings and backing guitar, militant drums... it all makes for a very stirring musical piece. But it doesn't have any real depth to it -- the overall ambience of the instrumentation might sound like it does, but the melody itself seems completely devoid of anything remotely trying to resemble what I think Godspeed! is going for here. I find it completely acceptable given it's the bands debut album, but it still just doesn't convey what it thinks it does.    Each of these tracks offers moments of great musical force by a band of stunning musicians but ultimately it is (for me) a look at the beginning of a band that would peak soon thereafter. Melodically speaking Godspeed! has never been challenged, and with this work we see the birth of that sensibility. For myself, however, what made Godspeed! a band that rose above most was when it went beyond mere aesthetics and into something far more powerful.     \\"Blaise Bailey Finegan III\\" this is not.

B000001EL7|5.0|Although there are a few flubs on Love Gun, it is truly the last great Kiss album.  Not entirely perfect, Love Gun is Kiss at the peak of their popularity.  The legendary live show that would spawn the awesome Alive II came from the Love Gun tour.  All bands peak, and Love Gun is the point where the monster that Kiss had become would begin to spring leaks and take on water afterwards.<br /><br />\\"I Stole Your Love\\" a Kiss classic and a live staple.  Simple, straight-up rock anthem.  Kiss created them.  Enough said.<br /><br />\\"Christine Sixteen\\" a song sang by an adult male about a hottie sixteen year old....hmmm.  Creepy?  Not then it wasn't.  Now would have been a different story.  The cheesy little piano riff is kinda silly but this is another Kiss classic.<br /><br />\\"I Got Love For Sale\\"  Love Gun starts off with three Gene Simmons' tunes in a row and that's kinda off-balancing.  This song sounds eerily reminiscent of so many other previous Kiss tunes (and future ones too).  Cool Ace riff and solo.  A rocker of a lesser degree.<br /><br />\\"Shock Me\\" Ace's first turn at the microphone.  His voice might have been an acquired taste.  This tune sounds a bit formulaic and stiff.  Ace sounds very uncomfortable singing here.  Still a great Kiss tune, cool riffs, and catchy hooks, there's an underlying tone here that you can't help but notice.<br /><br />\\"Tomorrow And Tonight\\" Basic rock and roll, that's what this tune is.  Maybe a little bland in the fact that it sounds familiar.  By Love Gun the Kiss sound was firmly laid down in concrete and that might have brought a few tunes down because they sounded too similar to other songs that Kiss had already come out with.<br /><br />\\"Love Gun\\" Trashy rock and roll.  Great.  Did Kiss invent the sexual innuendo?  No, but they created a whole genre of hard rock using them.  Love Gun is another word for . . . well...you know... and Kiss definitely had their share of women vying to become the holsters for their Love Guns.  Dig it.  This is where Motley Crue was born from.  Great, rocking tune.<br /><br />\\"Hooligan\\"  Peter Criss had hit the jackpot with \\"Beth\\"  then \\"Hard Luck Woman\\" and it was time for another payoff.  Unfortunately \\"Hooligan\\" wasn't it.  A cool little song with very cheesy lyrics, Kiss was pushing way too hard with this one.<br /><br />\\"Almost Human\\"  Great tune.  Gene Simmons had to have the dark, weird songs and this is one of them.  Where \\"God Of Thunbder\\" had come before, \\"Almost Human\\" followed.  Eerie and shifty, it was a strange, experimental sound for Kiss.<br /><br />\\"Plaster Caster\\"  In the early to mid seventies there was a particular groupie that went around making plaster casts of certain rock stars she had diddled.  Kiss was on her list and she took a little momento from each of the boys in makeup.  A Kiss staple and another sexual innuendo song.  Classic.<br /><br />\\"Then She Kissed Me\\"  Many felt that this retooled 50's tune was a miscue for Kiss, but I think it's better than \\"Hooligan\\" at least.  Nothing special, the boys in Kiss had to take a stab at a cover sooner or later.  Not entirely awful, just not that good, either.<br /><br />Overall, Love Gun is the end of an era.  Though their next studio album would be called Dynasty, this is where the Dynasty truly ended.  From here on out, things in the Kiss camp start to fall apart.<br /><br />Dig it!Guns.  Dig it.  This is where Motley Crue was born from.  Great, rocking tune. <br /> <br />\\"Hooligan\\"  Peter Criss had hit the jackpot with \\"Beth\\"  then \\"Hard Luck Woman\\" and it was time for another payoff.  Unfortunately \\"Hooligan\\" wasn't it.  A cool little song with very cheesy lyrics, Kiss was pushing way too hard with this one.   <br /> <br />\\"Almost Human\\"  Great tune. Classic. <br /> <br />\\"Then She Kissed Me\\"  Many felt that this retooled 50's tune was a miscue for Kiss, but I think it's better than \\"Hooligan\\" at least. B000001ELL|4.0|In 1979, Kiss released Dynasty, their first studio album since 1977's Love Gun.  Sure, in the two years since Love Gun, Kiss had pushed out four solo albums and Double Platnium, but Dynasty was the first collective album since Alive II.  Hailed by most critics as the beginning of the end for Kiss, Dynasty still had its share of gems as well as stinkers.<br /><br />\\"I Was Made For Lovin' You\\"  Straight forward disco-enticed tune.  Very cool Paul Stanley song despite its lack of truly rock origins.  One of the better tunes on Dynasty.<br /><br />\\"2,000 Man\\"  A Rolling Stones cover sung by Ace.  Very cool song.  Became a Kiss classic.<br /><br />\\"Sure Know Something\\" Another very breezy disco-tainted song, and yet another very cool song.  Paul knew how to sing disco and make it work.<br /><br />\\"Dirty Livin'\\" Is this a Kiss album?  That's what people must have been asking.  This song sounds like something out of The Mod Squad or Starsky & Hutch.  Strange song.  Listenable.  Actually...still a cool song.  You find yourself trying to hate Dynasty for its musical inconsistencies, and yet you're strangely mesmerized by it.<br /><br />\\"Charisma\\" Gene Simmons in a formulaic rock song.  Sounds kinda strained.  Not one of the better tunes here.  Sounds like filler.<br /><br />\\"Magic Touch\\"  this song sounds way too familiar.  Actually, it sounds almost like Paul Stanley's entier solo album and that's not a good thing.  Kinda boring.<br /><br />\\"Hard Times\\"  Ace.  Straining.  Bad lyrics.  Still listenable but you feel bad for Ace for the shoddy writing.<br /><br />\\"X-Ray Eyes\\"  Gene doesn't sound like he tried too hard on this album.  Maybe he was burned out from doing Kiss Meets The Phantom Of The Park.  This song is middle of the road, typical bulls*it.  Bummer.<br /><br />\\"Save You Love\\" Ace tune that sounds eerily reminiscent of his solo album.  Also soundz a little like \\"Shock Me\\" in Discoland. B000001EL3|5.0|In 1976, Kiss came out with two albums, Destroyer and Rock And Roll Over.  Destroyer took on a whole new direction for the formerly straight-ahead rockers.  Here Kiss found their biggest success by playing around the formula that had worked so well for them and heading into a more friendly, melodic direction.<br /><br />\\"Detroit Rock City\\" The greatest Kiss song of all time, hands down.  The strange intro and outro on the album detract a little from the song, although we get to hear Gene Simmons as a newscaster.<br /><br />\\"King Of The Night Time World\\"  Typical Paul Stanley tune aimed at the women of the world.  Rocking in every riff and verse.  This was the newer Kiss, the new Kiss sound.  Pop-catchy tunes. Not one of my personal favorites, but still a solid song.<br /><br />\\"God Of Thunder\\"  I love this song.  Gene Simmons was so f*cking cool when I was a kid.  He was scary.  He drooled blood.  He breathed fire.  Jesus, he was Satan incarnate, and that made him extremely cool!  This song is the personification of The Demon.  Awesome.<br /><br />\\"Great Expectations\\"  I don't understand why people love this song.  I think it's kinda stupid in its hedonistic sexually-retarded way.  Funny, actually.  Still, this was another stab at mainstream for Kiss. Kinda grand and popish.  Overblown when the choir kicks in.  This is definitely a step in the wrong direction.<br /><br />\\"Flaming Youth\\"  Straight-ahead rock tune.  A song that played to the teen of the world and spoke of rebellion.  The lyrics are a little cheesy and the riffs are a little light.  Not horrible, but not great either.  Could have been much better.<br /><br />\\"Sweet Pain\\" a cool tune with a redundant riff that goes on a little too long.  Very listenable.  The edge has been stripped off Ace's solos, however, and that detracts from the entire album.<br /><br />\\"Shout It Out Loud\\"  Rock Anthem!  Need I say more.  This song stems from the origins of \\"Nothin' To Lose.\\"  Kiss could come up with a tune with a hook and here it is.<br /><br />\\"Beth\\"  Peter Criss penned this tune for his wife and here it is. One of Kiss' biggest hits and an all-time classic.  Sweet and soothing, this song paved the way for Criss to sing at least one song on every album going forward until he left the band.<br /><br />\\"Do You Love Me\\"  a swanky, Paul Stanley classic.  Another ode to all of his women, this was where Paul came to life as The Lover.  Kiss created an image and Paul filled it.<br /><br />Overall, Kiss was moving away from their original rock sound to a more listener friendly sound,  Mainstream.  They would recieve huge popularity at this point and become household names.  This is the beginning of the end as the next two albums, followed up with Alive II, spell the last great chapter in Kisstory.  Everything after that is filled with stumbled and setbacks and mediocrity.  Enjoy a piece of the past where Kiss were kings.<br /><br />Dig it!h a tune with a hook and here it is.   <br /> <br />\\"Beth\\"  Peter Criss penned this tune for his wife and here it is. B000EULJLU|5.0|First off, I dont know what Mr. Censored was smoking when he was looking at the art work because frankly its the coolest packaging of a cd I've ever seen. It alone is a good reason to buy the album in stores instead of downloading it offline. Now onto the music. Vicarious is a good start (only minor complaint is Maynard's vocals are almost indecipherable), a heavy hard hitting cut which is probably on rotation at your local rock station and serves as a great intro. This leads to Jambi another hard rocker and then we come down with the lovely melodic psych rock of Wings for Marie/10,00 Days. After these trippy twins the heavy metal of the Pot is a sudden but very pleasant change. To be brief the rest of the album is great but the outstanding cut is Rosetta Stoned. What a hilarious title but it only hints at the chemical fueled trip Maynard narrates. His lyrics coupled with their very freaky delivery make for one crazy ride just in itself not to mention the rest of the band is at the top of their game backing him. Anyways definitely better than Laterlaus but nothing will ever exceed Aenima.

B000002UB3|5.0|To pick a favorite Beatles album is pretty much an impossible task.  Help!, Rubber Soul, Revolver, Sgt. Pepper's, Magical Mystery Tour, and The White Album are all incredible risk-taking albums that challenged a lot of what other pop groups were doing at the time.  When most bands change (Pet Sounds, comes to mind) their material gets initially ignored and then goes on become some of the best music ever made.  But what sets the Beatles apart from other \\"evolving\\" and \\"changing\\" bands was that they were able to satisfy themselves creatively as well as satisfy and blow fans' minds. I can go on all day about how great the Beatles are but I'm reviewing Abbey Road. <br />Even though Let it Be is the last album by the Beatles this is actually their final album since it was initially recorded after the Let It Be sessions.  There are your hit singles, \\"Something,\\" and \\"Come Together\\" but the whole album is great, with silly pop, \\"Maxwell's Silver Hammer, Octopuss's Garden\\" heavy distorted rock, \\"I Want You(She's So Heavy)\\" but what really catched my attention is the 2nd half of the album.  The 2nd half flows together and needs to be listened to in full to get a lot of the music and transitions between songs.  \\"You Never Give me Your Money, Golden Slumbers, Carry That Weight\\" and \\"The End\\" are all relatively short but when listened to together have a lot of meaning and feel to them.  Tensions and stress between the group were high, but the Beatles still managed to get some of the best material out of them and is still influential today.

0689853637|5.0|This is one of my favorite Robert Sabuda pop-up books, although I am admittedly a fan of all of them.  While this book is fairly monchromatic, the simple silver, glitter, and white papers highlight just how impressive the folds and cuts really are.  That mere paper can be engineered to leap off of the pages as deer, or swirl upward in a silvery river as fish, or open up as a cave to a den of foxes is truly amazing and it never fails to enchant me or my children.
