I would only recomend this novel to people who like to solve codes and computer nerds because anyone else wouldn't read through the whole book, it would put them to sleep.
B000FFJ85I|5.0|Okay folks, here's the deal with me. I guess I'm what you could call a \\"new\\" AFI fan, meaning that I haven't been with them since the days of \\"Very Proud of Ya.\\" Truth be told, I didn't even know this great band existed until a few years ago when, yes I'm saying it, I heard \\"Girl's Not Grey\\" on our local rock station (WEDG, 103.3) and saw the accompanying video on MTV. A few short days later, I ran out and purchased \\"Sing The Sorrow\\" and loved every song on it (including the techno-peppered \\"Death of Seasons,\\" and I am hardly a techno fan).  <br /> <br />Longing for more AFI, I decided to start purchasing some of the earlier albums in their catalog. The next one I purchased was \\"The Art Of Drowning,\\" and when I first listened to it I thought \\"wow...this is a really different style from 'Sing The Sorrow'.\\" But I found it to be an amazing piece of musical art nonetheless; standout tracks for me including \\"Of Greetings and Goodbyes,\\" \\"Wester,\\" \\"Days Of The Phoenix,\\" \\"6 To 8,\\" and \\"Morningstar.\\" The next purchase I made was the much-heralded \\"Black Sails In The Sunset,\\" and again I was thoroughly impressed. Favorites of mine on that album include \\"Narrative of Soul Against Soul,\\" \\"God Called In Sick Today,\\" and \\"Malleus Malleficarum\\" (I probably spelled that last one wrong, but whatever...). Only three albums in, these guys were quickly becoming one of my all-time favorite bands. <br /> <br />With my purchase of the four-song \\"All Hallows E.P.,\\" that feeling was only strengthened. I had no idea that it was this band that originally wrote the classic tune that is \\"Totalimmortal.\\" Unfortunately, just about all of the credit for that went to the much lesser band known as The Offspring because they covered it on the soundtrack to \\"Me, Myself, and Irene.\\"  <br /> <br />Anyway, a friend of mine then did me a huge favor. He burned me copies of AFI's first four releases: \\"Very Proud of Ya,\\" \\"Answer That and Stay Fashionable,\\" \\"Shut Your Mouth and Open Your Eyes,\\" and the \\"A Fire Inside EP.\\" My friend stated that these four releases represent a very different AFI than I had become accustomed to, and he was right. I'm going to say this straight up: \\"Very Proud of Ya\\" and \\"Answer That and Stay Fashionable\\" are albums that consist of 95% terrible songs. They sound exactly like the droves of other three-chord skate punk bands that were around at the time of their release, with no attempt to sound different at all. It has always been my opinion that these first couple albums sound mostly like early Offspring, and for those who are wondering that isn't a good thing. The other two were slightly forgiveable in that they featured a more unique sound, but only by a small stretch.  <br /> <br />Fast-forward to 2006, and AFI's newest release \\"decemberunderground.\\" It sounds very, very different from anything this band has done in the past, but you know what? Change is to be expected when it comes to a band's music. What, would you \\"hardcore\\" fans rather have them put out ten more albums that sound like \\"Answer That and Stay Fashionable?\\" I for one would not, and I am happy that they have not chosen that (boring) route. For those of you waiting to see them put out \\"Even Prouder of Ya\\" or \\"Shut Your Mouth and Open Your Eyes Part Deux,\\" you're going to be waiting a long, long time. This is band that, thankfully, progresses and matures with each successive release. No longer is Davey Havok whining about mohawks, cereal, skateboarding, and jocks, but rather writing lyrics that, although rather deep and metaphorical, can be related to by just about anybody. And the music being played by the other members of the band? Well, let's just say that Mark (former guitarist) and Geoff (former bassist) aren't fit to shine Jade and Hunter's shoes or carry their luggage. <br /> <br />Anyway, my favorite songs on this album (so far) are \\"Prelude 12/21\\" (easily the best opener AFI have ever put on an album, despite being accused of having a \\"50 Cent\\" beat), single \\"MissMurder,\\" \\"Summer Shudder,\\" \\"Love Like Winter,\\" \\"The Killing Lights,\\" and \\"Endlessly, She Said.\\" I've only had the album for one day, and as such it is going to require more time for all of the songs to grow on me. To those of you who have accused AFI of selling out (which they haven't, but just for the sake of argument), with all due respect please take your heads out of your behinds. All they have done is grow and further refine their already excellent sound. Make no bones about it, I'm not too big on the increased use of techno/electronica on this album, but it definitely gives it a new atmosphere of sound.  <br /> <br />And no, AFI have not become \\"just another whiny MTV band.\\" That title will always be reserved for lesser bands such as Simple Plan and Dashboard Confesssional.

It just doesn't fit Chopin's music all that well, but it's still worth buying and listening to thousands of times.

B000CNFC76|4.0|The Greatest Game Ever Played tells the triumphant true story of amateur golfer Francis Quimet, who captured the imagination of America at the U.S. Open Championship during the early 1900's. <br /> <br />It's a well written, well acted, well made film.  And although there is very little to be found in the story that hasn't been done before, (poor son of immigrant makes good in sporting arena, rises above class obstacles, gets the girl) there is pleasure in seeing these plot points handled deftly.  The film is well paced and is indeed strong enough to withstand the fact that we know Francis will win the tournament in the end. <br /> <br />Bill Paxton is becoming one of my favorite directors in addition to being one of my favorite actors.  His presentation here is very stylistic and faithful to the time in which the story takes place.  The recurrent and surreal \\"gnat on the ball\\" effects might be used a few times too many, but I understand why Paxton utilized this technique.  It helps legendize the tale and gives it a bit of Paul Bunyan quality.  It also keeps the film from becoming too dry or period. <br /> <br />It's a fine film to watch as a family.  Parents and kids alike can enjoy this one together.  That is a rarity these days.  It certainly deserves its place among Disney's best non-animated family features.  I recommend it highly.
B0000024ZT|5.0|Bruce Springsteen was often called the new Bob Dylan during his early career, and Greetings From Asbury Park, NJ is the prime reason why. Those who called him the new Dylan pointed to Springsteen's imagery and stream-of-consciousness lyrics, which resembled Highway 61 Revisited-era tunes.     But Greetings is a whole different beast entirely. It certainly owes a debt to Dylan lyrically, but musically it's more expansive. It sure ain't Born to Run, but you can feel the fire growing, and there are some definite classics here: \\"Blinded by the Light,\\" (later covered poorly by Manfred Mann) \\"Growin' Up,\\" (my personal favorite) \\"Lost in the Flood,\\" and \\"Spirit in the Night\\" are all great, great songs from a hungry young talent. And the rest is awfully good, too. Springsteen is a bit more optimistic here; even when he gets downbeat, there is an overall excitement to the album that keeps it from being overly depressing.    Considering where Springsteen was headed, this is rather surprising. In fact, one could hardly guess that in less than a decade, he would release the barebones (but brilliant) Nebraska. It's an exciting, exhilirating album that could easily be ranked among the best debuts ever (including Led Zeppelin, Please Please Me, Crosby, Stills, and Nash, and whatever else you have to throw at it). There's no doubt that Bruce would improve on the elements that make Greetings an undeniable success. Indeed, The Wild, the Innocent, and the E Street Shuffle, released the following year, shows impressive lyrical and musical expansion. But there's something so youthful and breathtaking about this album that it remains a wholly unique gem in Springsteen's catalog, and as good an album as any to start listening to him.

B000F6IOC0|4.0|The first Underworld movie was a modest box office hit but enough, apparently, to spawn a sequel that continues the war that rages between vampires and werewolves. Director Len Wiseman pillaged visuals from both The Matrix and The Crow movies in the first one and this time around borrows a bit from The Lord of the Rings films in Evolution's prologue. However, from that point on, he strikes out on his own with decent results as he manages to improve on the characters and story he created in the first film.<br /><br />You have to give Wiseman credit - stylistically Evolution is consistent with its predecessor. It helps that he had a hand in crafting the story (and the film's mythos) and directed both movies while also advancing the mythology that grounds everything. He also changes settings, taking us away from the gothic European cities and into the countryside with ancient castles.<br /><br />As with the first film, Wiseman doesn't skimp on the R rated violence and gore, refusing to pander to the more lucrative PG-13 crowd (who would've just rented/bought the R version on DVD). He has improved upon his first film with Evolution which has a slightly more urgent tone because more is at stake. His direction is more confident and he wisely doesn't try to drag things out, keeping the running time well under two hours. Wiseman also manages to top most of the action set pieces in the first Underworld film without overreaching himself, including a climatic fight scene that is truly satisfying. Although, I have no idea how he'll top this one if the powers that be ask him to make it a trilogy... perhaps a prequel?<br /><br />There is an audio commentary by director Len Wiseman, production designer Patrick Tatopoulos, second unit director Brad Martin and editor Nicolas De Toth. This track is production anecdote-heavy as they talk about what it was like working on a given day and the challenges of shooting on a limited budget. This is actually quite an informative track with nary a lull anywhere.<br /><br />\\"Bloodlines: From Script to Screen\\" examines the origins of this movie. Wiseman had a lot of story content left over from the first film and its success allowed a sequel to further the mythos as he had envisioned it.<br /><br />\\"The Hybrid Theory\\" examines the film's visual effects which are 3-4 times more than the first film. The result is a seamless blend of CG and practical effects.<br /><br />\\"Making Monsters Roar\\" takes a look at the creature effects. The filmmakers consciously wanted to improve on the creature suits and make them more flexible so that they move more realistically and fluidly.<br /><br />\\"The War Rages On\\" examines the stunts performed on the movie. Much more ambitious ones were planned that were faster and more aggressive than what we saw in the first Underworld movie.<br /><br />\\"Building a Saga\\" takes a look at the production design. The scale of this film was much bigger with old castles that involved a lot of building of interior sets. Wiseman consciously wanted to move away from an urban setting to more of a period piece vibe.<br /><br />\\"Music and Mayhem\\" examines the sound design, the film's score and how it enhanced the drama of the movie, manipulating how the audience felt about a given scene.<br /><br />Finally, there is a music video for \\"Her Portrait in Black\\" by metal band Atreyu done in the style of the film with lots of clips from it. Basically, the lead singer comes from what has been called the Cookie Monster school of vocals.ith nary a lull anywhere. <br /> <br />\\"Bloodlines: From Script to Screen\\" examines the origins of this movie. Wiseman had a lot of story content left over from the first film and its success allowed a sequel to further the mythos as he had envisioned it. <br /> <br />\\"The Hybrid Theory\\" examines the film's visual effects which are 3-4 times more than the first film. The result is a seamless blend of CG and practical effects. <br /> <br />\\"Making Monsters Roar\\" takes a look at the creature effects. The filmmakers consciously wanted to improve on the creature suits and make them more flexible so that they move more realistically and fluidly. <br /> <br />\\"The War Rages On\\" examines the stunts performed on the movie. Much more ambitious ones were planned that were faster and more aggressive than what we saw in the first Underworld movie. <br /> <br />\\"Building a Saga\\" takes a look at the production design. The scale of this film was much bigger with old castles that involved a lot of building of interior sets. Wiseman consciously wanted to move away from an urban setting to more of a period piece vibe. <br /> <br />\\"Music and Mayhem\\" examines the sound design, the film's score and how it enhanced the drama of the movie, manipulating how the audience felt about a given scene. <br /> <br />Finally, there is a music video for \\"Her Portrait in Black\\" by metal band Atreyu done in the style of the film with lots of clips from it. B000F3A7LE|5.0|I didn't know this, but there were two different versions of Exposure. The first CD release was significantly remixed from the album mix, and Daryl Hall added some new vocals (according to Robert Fripp's engaging and informative liner notes for this issue).     The excellent new two-disc edition gives the orignal album mix on one disc and on the second disc gives all the tracks from the CD-mix edition, plus some original Daryl Hall vocal versions from 1977/8 that were never released due to pressure from Hall's management and record company.    The remastering is great. Disc two (the mix I'd never heard) sounds superb and I'm sure disc one sounds just as good. The way EVERY character has something that we get to explore, even if it is just a tad, we still get a sense of who they are.  They don't just throw in a major character and not explain him.  Even Pitt's stoner character was pretty well explained.<br /><br />Basically I am doing too much rambling because it would easily be the longest review ever if I shared all my thoughts. But this is why you don't just give every movie 5 stars here, cause a flick like this comes along and you really have to think about all your past reviews.  No thinkin on this one, I am a kung fu movie fan, and I certainly got what I wanted.  Btw-you  people do know this is a fu movie, right? I didn't hear any hi-ya's, but they beautifully captured the spirit of a old school kung fu flick on this one.<br /><br />I will tell yuo what I was told 2 days ago by 3 other people, \\"you are an idiot if you watch any movie before this one\\", oh god were they right.<br /><br />Btw- I know I didn't talk abou the actual movie, that is because it is magnificent, and I can't allow myself to spoil a second for you.  All the other reviewers are dead on with their 5 stars, now click on the new and used section, there ya go...<br /><br />Also the version I am reviewing is the  widescreened one disc unrated version with no special features.  Good enough for me.<br /><br />-CAN'T BELIEVE I HAEV TO FREAKING EDIT THIS-<br /><br />To the reviewer above me, how the hell is this a 4 star movie.  You had better nto tell me that reservoir dogs, jackie brown, or pulp fiction are better than this. B000FILW86|5.0|Cheap Trick has a LOT of die hard fans, and they all seem to meet on Amazon.  And all of these fans love the band for different reasons, and argue why the band either has excited them or let them down with each release, while other fans feel the opposite.  Sometimes the band is too hard, sometimes not hard enough, sometimes too raw, sometimes too polished. <br /> <br />This release should satisfy everyone into Cheap Trick, as well as attract new rock fans.  It takes from elements of every Cheap Trick album and blends them all together in a fresh new CD that sounds like a greatest hits in and of itself.  Heck, the tunes are so catchy, that when I read others list their favorite songs from the CD (and remember, being a diverse fan base, everyone's favorites are different), every single song immediately plays in my head.  After one listen. <br />In a world of 99 cent downloads, it's great to have a full album of quality rock from start to finish. <br /> <br />Dirty details: <br />-Robin's vocals are better than ever.  His absolute best record. <br />-Rick's guitars aren't loud enough.  Are they ever, though? <br />-Tom's tone and playing are AMAZING.  Better than All Shook Up. <br />-The album is LOUD.  And this is great.  EXCELLENT production.   <br /> <br />I'm incredibly thankful that Cheap Trick continue to put out new music, as bands younger than them are already permanently in retro-mode with no thoughts for new material.  There is not a single weak track here, and I'd love to hear the whole album played live.  I'll definitely buy the Japanese release too for the Mando Ragga bonus track.

B000FILW86|4.0|Let me start off by warning people that this band was even only to KISS in my heart in the 70s, so I am ultra critical in my judgement when they release a new album. The passion I had for this band starting on that day in late '78 when Dad brought me home Budokan(the yellow vinyl import version, which I think was the only one available at the time) was intense, and I've stuck with them through patchy albums(The Doctor), the \\"song doctor\\" years (Lap-Busted), and everything in-between. To me, nothing can touch the 1st album up to All Shook Up-period. Everything after that is a separate entity in my mind. Kind of like KISS after Love Gun, Van Halen after Roth, heck, after Fair Warning!, well, you get the idea. I'm a purist, so sue me LOL! OK, on to the review:<br /><br />Let's get the negatives out of the way quickly, and there's only 2-#1 is the first 12 seconds of Welcome To The World. Kinda, uh...G@Y is the only word that comes to mind, not in the Qweer Eye way, but, uh..maybe \\"corny\\" is a better word? OK, after that, WTTW is a cool enough song. Not a great opener, but I'll get over it. :>)<br /> Negative #2 is Come On Come On Come On. They already had a much better song with this title(ok, ok, that was only 2 C'mon C'mon's, I get it). It's just kind of a filler track, not bad, but just one of those average, sounds-like-it-was-written-in-5-minutes type of songs.<br /><br />  Now, let me say that Special One was a let down, not very immediate, very mid-tempo, etc. Some cool stuff on it(Pop Drone, Best Friend, My Obsession), a bit 'deeper' in some respects, but a bit lacking in great melodies, hooks, etc. All of the trademarks that make CT what they are were a bit AWOL on Special One. ROCKFORD makes up for it in spades. There are strong hooks, the great Beatle-esque melodies, loud guitars, and just better songs. I would say it has elements of Standing On The Edge(Little Sister type vibe), CT'97, mixed with some of the elements of classic 70s Trick. I'm not going to do a song-by-song analysis, but some highlights for me are All Those Years(a leftover from the Monster sessions that Tom originaly sang, now re-done with Robin AND Tom on the chorus). This song is excellent and it's great to hear Tom again on vocals. O Claire is an oldie from the 70s, if I remember right, that was never used, and it's a great, ELO-Lennon inspired song that could have been on All Shook Up right along with World's Greatest Lover. Dream The Night Away, Perfect Stranger, If It Takes A Lifetime are other highlights for me.<br /><br /> The 2 Jack Douglas assisted tracks are also great(Decaf & One More). Rick's guitar tone is a bit more \\"classic\\" sounding, and there's more dynamics. Considering CT's 1st album from '77 is my favorite Trick album, I'd love to see Douglas do a whole album with the band again.<br /><br />It's great to hear some strings and keyboards again, done the RIGHT way, not the cheesy 80s Doctor era samples and sound effects. I was always a fan of what Tom Werman did with the band in that regard, adding the Who's Next styled synth patterns and ELO-esque strings(Way Of The World)....it just adds so much depth and richness to the band's sound. I know the band has a negative feeling towards Werman, but I'd be curious to know how much he had to do with developing the band's trademark 70s sound. Now if only In Color didn't sound like a blanket was over the band as was as crisp and punchy as Dream Police...but I digress.<br /><br />  Rockford is in my estimation, the best thing they've done since Next Position Please. Yes, Standing On The Edge, Doctor, etc. all had a few great tracks on each album, but I'd say Rockford, unlike those albums, is solid almost all the way through. There's no She's Got Motion, Good Girls Go To Heaven, or Space to skip over on Rockford. I always said Enuff Znuff made more CT sounding albums in the late 80s/early 90s than CT themselves. Listen to New Thing off EZ's 1st album....now picture Robin singing it. See what Imean?? LOL<br /><br />Cheap Trick will probably never again sound like The Who/Beatles/Move/Elo influenced band of the 70s, so waiting for Dream Police II is wishful thinking. It seems that the band has moved away from that core set of influences ever since All Shook Up, and has morphed into another beast. The 80s definitely changed the band's sound and Rick's writing style, and that seems to be the groundwork for which everything since is based on. If you're cool with that, you will love this album. I give this album 4 stars, and the only thing keeping it from getting 5 is the fact that it's not one of the \\"untouchables\\" from 1977-80. Hey, I gotta have standards! BUY ROCKFORD NOW!ever again sound like The Who/Beatles/Move/Elo influenced band of the 70s, so waiting for Dream Police II is wishful thinking. It seems that the band has moved away from that core set of influences ever since All Shook Up, and has morphed into another beast. The 80s definitely changed the band's sound and Rick's writing style, and that seems to be the groundwork for which everything since is based on. If you're cool with that, you will love this album. I give this album 4 stars, and the only thing keeping it from getting 5 is the fact that it's not one of the \\"untouchables\\" from 1977-80. Hey, I gotta have standards! BUY ROCKFORD NOW!

B0009A1AS2|3.0|This album was actually frustrating to my ears. Why? Oh, simply because the title track is one of the best songs Dream Theater have written in the past 15 years, but the rest of the album is trite and crappy. I'll review the astounding title track in more detail:    Octavarium, the 24 minute beast shock-full of nuggets and references to other songs and albums and bands, has a very cool theme. The theme is, in a nutshell, how we move in circles. The story ends where it began. This is where we came in. Everything is a circle.     Octavarium has 5 parts. Someone Like Him, Medicate Me, Full Circle, Intervals, and Razor's Edge. To further emphasize the point of moving in circles, the album Octavarium ends with part V, and the album started with part VI (the album starts with Root of all Evil, the third song in Mike Portnoy's AA saga, and it starts with step or part VI).     Octavarium begins quite atmopherically, with Jordan Rudess heavily borrowing from Pink Floyd. The first three minutes or so of Octavarium are entirely dedicated to Mr. Rudess and his Continuum, a weird instrument that sounds like a heavily reverbed guitar and looks like a sort of pedal steel.     Then it kicks in, with the main keyboard melody of Octavarium (which is also the main vocal line of Medicate Me) starting. Then the song slows down, a quite georgeous acoustic guitar line starts from John Petrucci: James LaBrie starts singing over this, effectively starting Someone Like Him. This part of the song is very haunting, and it reiterates the point of Carpe Diem made by the other 20+ song in the Dream Theater oeuvre, A Change of Seasons.     Someone Like Him ends with Myung playing a very cool bass line that reminds me of Chris Squire. This bassline starts Medicate Me.     Medicate Me ends with James LaBrie singing \\"...can't you stop what's happening?\\". As soon as LaBrie sings that last \\"...ing\\" Jordan Rudess starts one of his best Dream Theater keyboard solos, and this lasts like three minutes. This part of Octavarium is one of Jordan Rudess's career highlights. This solo also starts off Full Circle, where the insane references to other pop culture piles up and up. For the next 3-5 minutes after the last words in Full Circle, it is all Rudess and Petrucci (who had laid back for the first half or so of the song). Rudess and Petrucci do this crazy chromatic unison run very reminiscent of the unisons in Metropolis part 1. Then Intervals starts, with James LaBrie referencing every song on the album. This leads to LaBrie screaming TRAPPED INSIDE THIS OCTAVARIUM four times.    Razor's Edge, one of the most beautiful parts of a song in the entire Dream Theater catalogue, has only two verses. After the singing is done, Petrucci solos. It is one of the best and most beautiful and atmospheric and downright jaw dropping solos Petrucci has ever played.     Octavarium ends with an F note.     Now, as you see above, I love the Octavarium title track very much. So you see how frustrating it is for me to try to listen to the other crappy songs on the album.
B000ETRCMQ|4.0|This 2005 film won Felicity Huffman an academy award nomination.  I can understand why because it is a difficult, complex and subtle role and requires fine acting ability.  She sure does show it too.  She's cast a woman named Bree, formerly known as a man named Sidney.  She's has been living as a woman for several years and is about to undergo a sex change operation, been working hard to achieve this goal, undergoing years of physiological therapy and always wears lace and satin and meticulous makeup.  She's a quiet person with a deep sense of decorum and works hard at two jobs in order to save up the money for the operation.  She feels she is a woman in every way but one.<br /><br />Then, from out of the blue, she discovers that she has fathered a son 17 years before.  The young man, played by Kevin Zegers, is a street hustler.  She lives in Los Angeles but she flies to New York to bail him out of jail.  And now begins their cross country drive to the west coast.  She has to be back in LA for the surgery.  And he wants to go west so he can become a porn star.  She doesn't tell him her true identity.  He thinks she is a church lady who wants to reform him.<br /><br />The scene is now set for conflict and drama.  Some of it is humorous but the humor is a quiet chuckle, not the kind that makes me laugh out loud.  Mostly, it made me do some deep thinking about human nature.  I enjoyed the film with one caveat however.  Felicity Huffman never seemed like a man.  She was always a woman to me.  Maybe that's because I've seen her work in Desperate Housewives which is very much about women.  And maybe it's just because I knew she was a real woman all along.<br /><br />Generally though, I think this was a fine film with a well deserved Academy Award nomination for Ms. Huffman.  Recommended.
B00005JLEU|4.0|What is so great about the last 5 Miyazaki movies? I'd say not much. There's certainly a lot of good stuff, unparalleled animation, and more unparalleled animation. But once you get past the novelty of the weirdness, the strange creatures, what do you have? Not much. There isn't really much of a plot here. C'mon, to those who talk about the symbolism or the deeper meaning, do you really think you know what goes on in Miyazaki's mind? The guy keeps getting pulled out of retirement, maybe in there is some statement that he just wants to stay retired.     And to those who say Miyazaki is their 7 year old's favorite director, c'mon! OK, maybe they like Totoro (and Barney), but don't let them see Spirited Away, otherwise they'll be so scared they'll end up sleeping in your bed until they're 13. His last 5 movies should never be allowed to be watched by any 7 year old by any responsible parent.     Look at it this way, Miyazaki is only revered now because he's only done 1/2 dozen such movies, if he'd done 30 movies like this we'd all be yawning. People are highly rating this stuff because it's novel and chic to rate it high.     Miyazaki cannot be pigeonholed. He doesn't want to be your kid's favorite director, nor does he want to be the chic director of the year only to be tossed like dirty laundry by the next Tom Cruise movie that comes out.     This movie has serious animation, period. Miyazaki gets a 5 star for the breadth of his work. This movie gets a solid 3.

Cale's \\"Naturally\\" decades ago. And no reason is given for Anthony's switch to the KGB, probably because Follett couldn't think of a reason either.  <br /> <br />What Follett's strength is, and has always been is that he writes the characters with great depth and his books are easy to read and follow. B00007LTIA|5.0|Dammit, this is not pretentious.  There was a time in rock when bands not only had the ambition to make something different and challenging, but actually did it with the blessing of their record company.  And people bought the stuff in droves.  Yes were enormously popular at this time, and people liked their ambitions.  This is one of my all time favorite albums.  I loved the fact that in its original LP format, it had 4 side long songs, roughly 20 minutes apiece.  It is a work not dissimilar to a long work by any famous composer.  I love all the tracks here.  From the intense opening verse of The Revealing Science of God to the playfulness of Ritual, this maybe Yes's greatest album.  While punk musicians hated bands like Yes, ELP, and Pink Floyd, these bands' music has outlasted any crap punk threw (sometimes literally) at us.  The punk bands that went on changed their musical outlook (like The Clash..their later work was much more ambitious than their earlier stuff) made lasting work.  Do not fault those who are ambitious and are trying new things...fault yourself...

The beat is nice and Rihanna sounds great on the track. I can relate to the lyrics in the song. It's very catchy and touching. <br /> <br />11. A Girl Like Me- This is another slow jam that just talks about how different she is. It's a good song and good choice for the albums theme song. The beat is hot too. <br /> <br />12. A Million Miles Away- This ballad reminds me of \\"Now I Know\\" from her first album, but you can tell she's worked on her vocals a lot because this song is touching and sad. It brings tears to my eyes sometimes. The piano with her voice sounds so nice together. <br /> <br />13. If It's Lovin That You Want (Remix)- The beat on this track is amazing. I love it more than the original, just because of the beat. For the most part, it matches well with the way it's originally sung. It's definetely a hot track, and it was smart to add another dance song on the album. <br /> <br />All in all, this album is very good and I hope you'll be pleased by it, as I was.
B000CZ0Q5W|5.0|I am not a big fan of Pat Metheny -- I don't know much about his other CDs, but I have to say that I absolutely love this one. The song Last Train Home is probably one of my favorite songs of all time. There is just something about it that takes my breath away. The same can also be said of the other songs on the disc as well. I highly recommend this CD.
B00006LLNU|3.0|At least in concept, this album is an excercise in minimalism. That is not to say, stripped down music like Spoon's \\"Kill the Moonlight.\\" The lush instrumentation and lighted vocals characteristic of Sigur Ros remain. But, this is an album with: <br />a) No title <br />b) No song titles <br />c) Blank pages instead of liner notes in the album booklet. <br />d) The use of one lone phrase for all vocals on the album (you-cy-low) <br />This isn't a big stretch if you have heard their music. The concept was to let the sounds be interpreted specially for each individual, and it does. But this album is a *relative* failure compared to Takk and especially Agaetis Byrjun. Relative is key, because the angelic music still puts them leagues above other bands in originality and ambience.  <br /> <br />Rather simply, this isn't Sigur Ros' best work. The other two albums are far more cohesive, easily listenable in their durations. ( ) sounds much better by picking out one song at a time. Honestly, listening to the whole thing at once will put me to sleep. Given a pick of one such track, I would chose the 4th, this albums most amazing song, and one of Sigur Ros' best. You see, the whole \\"you-cy-low\\" thing works for one 6.5 minute epic song. But when the whole album is deriviatives of this, you wish that those Hopelandish speakers would broaden their vocabulary. <br /> <br />All in all, I wouldn't deterr you from giving this album a listen. But, I would strongly suggest that any music fan could distinguish the superiority of Takk and Agaetis. At least listen to the 6 minute epic that is Untitled #4. <br /> <br />Rating: 7.0/10.0
B000BYA5GO|4.0|Commercials made this movie seem a lot more humourous than it is, using the few instances of Yuri talking about arms dealing like he's a company spokesman, but that has little to do with the overall tone of the movie. Nonetheless it drew me in quickly with it's unique no-nonsense realism and conversational tone, leading me to think it could be a great film early on, but when it started to jump rather than flow from one thing to another I didn't feel like I was watching a story unfold as much as being given a bunch of puzzle pieces to put together. It has a lot of great parts, many of which are informative about the international arms trade, but it's pretty impossible to rate it as a whole, because it never really becomes one. It tries to do too much, and the amount of shifts in focus, redirections of viewer attention, ended up leaving me not fully invested in the outcome(s). There's also a difficulty in suspending disbelief as Nicolas Cage plays the same character over a 10+ year period. Overall though I think this movie is interesting and unique enough to be worth recommending.  <br />
0060512806|4.0|Having read so many complaints about the book's ending, I feel compelled to throw in my own two cents (without giving anything away). I thought the very ending-- with the symbolic and poetic power of its final image, with its resonance with (and contrast to) the claustrophobic secrecy of the whole book up to that point-- as well as a further development of the Lord of the Rings resonance-- was beautiful.    Not the greatest book I've ever read; it certainly pales compared to Gravity's Rainbow (which this book feels like, at least for the first half). But make no mistake-- Stephenson knew exactly what he was doing with the ending!
B000E97HIA|5.0|That sums it up. This is a return to booty rocking funky A$$ Prince! The man is in his 40s and he can still bring it. He's a musical genius, and I'm happy he has the freedom to make the music HE wants and isn't worrying about airplay. Good CD, great artist, and I hope young people give him a chance and discover what a real musician can do.
B000002LIX|5.0|... and this is the last, most literate treatise on the sparks that fly between those three discrete phenomena that I can remember. Nothing has come close ever since: this is the quintessential Los Angeles spaced-out, drugged-out rock slab upon which millions of minds were soul-sacrificed since the day of release.<br /><br />\\"Ritual\\" is a bright light among the used bins, screaming out at you from two (!!!) distinct and meaningful slices of cover art, and if memory serves me, I snatched up both for the hell of it. The first listen was at a party on a sweltering summer afternoon into spacy hot evening, the CD thrust upon me by a buddy who was also in a pretty popular indie-rock band at the time who claimed to have been inspired and changed already, two days after its release. I bought it the next day. I made out to it, listened to it on road trips, put it on mixtapes for friends, stared at the cover, set it in stone. I carried the novena thingy in my wallet for a while too.<br /><br />A little context: the pseudo-political ramblings of a very heady Perry were consistent with the open-eyed awakening of (true) gen-X youth of the time: a time when there was no internet spoon-feeding and word-of-mouth was the order of the day. I seem to recall a real stream of interest in generational politics and a true alternative ethic: Fugazi and the whole DC thing were exploding in air, Douglas Coupland had just written his book, China and Eastern Europe were simmering and worldwide global crapola was everywhere. The state of the environment was resurrected as a social issue. We were finally figuring out that we had to live in a world with something called AIDS. Even frivolous pop-culture stuff like \\"My Own Private Idaho\\" was part of this generational, twenty-something awakening. \\"Ritual\\" was the soundtrack to this revolution of the mind that seemed to be erupting in my heart and those of my friends. Something was changing.<br /><br />The album is brilliant. Nothing is filler. It was like a scream from L.A., and the music was all over the map. Perry's vocals were attacks. The rhythm section was apocalyptic and buzzing. And good grief - Navarro - the first Guitar God of the 90's - what ground he didn't cover in the initial five tracks is mopped up with sonic reverb and melancholy in the end, a wan, wasted vision closing with the underrated \\"Classic Girl\\", a sunset to a sonic excursion on a scope with the very best epic rock from any era. This was the 90's at its doorstep, and \\"Ritual\\" set the tone for the entire decade, with a truly astonishing and fertile underground scene earthquaking in its afterglow. Everything that came after seemed to spring from this source: from Jawbox to grrl rock (Babes, L7, and so on), from shoegaze to garage rock (did MBV and Dinosaur really tour? what I wouldn't give today), from music to movies to political activism to interpersonal change... everything just erupted after \\"Ritual\\". Just erupted.<br /><br />The importance, vision, and intensity of this album cannot be overstated. It's one for the ages.r. It was like a scream from L.A., and the music was all over the map. Perry's vocals were attacks. The rhythm section was apocalyptic and buzzing. And good grief - Navarro - the first Guitar God of the 90's - what ground he didn't cover in the initial five tracks is mopped up with sonic reverb and melancholy in the end, a wan, wasted vision closing with the underrated \\"Classic Girl\\", a sunset to a sonic excursion on a scope with the very best epic rock from any era. This was the 90's at its doorstep, and \\"Ritual\\" set the tone for the entire decade, with a truly astonishing and fertile underground scene earthquaking in its afterglow. Everything that came after seemed to spring from this source: from Jawbox to grrl rock (Babes, L7, and so on), from shoegaze to garage rock (did MBV and Dinosaur really tour? what I wouldn't give today), from music to movies to political activism to interpersonal change... everything just erupted after \\"Ritual\\". Just erupted. <br /> <br />The importance, vision, and intensity of this album cannot be overstated. It's one for the ages.
B00005JKLZ|3.0|H.G. Wells was, let's say, a mediocre socialist, journalist and historian who brilliantly and imaginatively wrote social commentary and criticism in the form of science fiction. He wrote a good number of other things too, but he is best known for his science fiction, and for good reason; among his writings, his science fiction is undisputedly the best, and, among science fiction authors, he is undisputedly one of the greatest of all time. In the 1960 George Pal movie version of Wells' classic, The Time Machine, one of the characters is made to pose the question at the end: If you were reduced to having access to only three books, which three would you choose? If I were forced to choose between the Communist Manifesto and The Time Machine as one of my selections, I would definitely choose The Time Machine.<br /><br />That being said, however, the first thing I would say about the 2002 Dreamworks film, 'The Time Machine,' is that it does not succeed as an adaptation of Wells' novel. Some of the characters names are the same, some of the dates are the same, the title is the same--there is a time machine in both--and that is pretty near the end of the resemblance. To see how far the film departs from the novel, perhaps it can suffice to point out that whereas Wells' story avoids the problem of 'temporal paradox,' simply in terms of the events and action, the plot of this movie completely hinges upon it, even in terms of motive. Perhaps it could be seen as a simplified--or amplified--Wells, but none of the characters or situations resemble enough those of the novel; the only thing in common is a divided future humanity which has evolved into cannibalism, which, by itself, simply does not offer enough to tell a story. So we are really left only with what hinges on the temporal paradox narrative.<br /><br />That being said, is it fair to compare this movie to the book, or to the 1960 version, which was loosely based upon it? Well, yes, to this extent: Is it fair to say that the author of the 2002 screenplay deserves the title--based on this new yarn--as one of the greatest science fiction writers of all time? Answer: no.<br /><br />That being said, is the movie any good? Yes.<br /><br />The story, it seems to me, only succeeds in speaking about technology 'going too far.' A scientist, who at first thinks 'there is no such thing' as going too far with technology, eventually changes his mind--too late for his first romance (in 1899)--but in time for his second (800,000 years later). At first he has a great passion for science, but this soon gets subordinated to his intention to change the past for personal (albeit humanly understandable) reasons. He makes a time machine. It works, but it doesn't work; he can go back in time, but he can't change the past. Dazed, and forgetting his training in elementary logic, he can't understand why, and takes a needless trip into the future instead of re-reading his logic books. Along the way he finds more evidence that technology never really does what it is supposed to, and gradually decides to join the native castaways of the future, using (and sacrificing) his machine to try to at least undo the damage that technology over the millennia has done, at least in terms of its effects on the future (he can't use the machine for the purpose it was constructed, but that is true for all machines, so that is no criticism of it). And so: he was 'a man ahead of his time' (maybe so--for 1899--at least for a professor of applied mechanics).<br /><br />A thin story line, but fun, with due references made to both Wells' novel and the 1960 film (given its title), complete with satisfying cameo appearances for those thinking that the movie might have something to do with the novel by Wells.<br /><br />Having said that, it can also be said that the film does succeed and even earn a niche, on a visceral and visual level, among cinematic depictions of time travel. This is perhaps best summarized and underscored by some footage for the film's opening scenes (one that, I think mistakenly, was dropped to the cutting room floor): the hero is shown demonstrating a Crookes' Radiometer (also known as a light mill), whose vanes (inside a bulb) are propelled into a circular motion by sunshine. We see this image throughout the film; most notably by the time machine itself, with its spinning Fresnel, 'lighthouse' lenses, which, upon fully opening through centrifugal forces, even as the buds of a flower, somehow serve to bend light so as to embrace and enclose the time machine in a 'sphere of electromagnetic radiation' (interestingly, the light starts out as two funnels, facing in opposite directions and connected at the spout--somewhat resembling the 'light cones' of the special theory of relativity--with this analogy, one could say that when the light is bent into a sphere, the 'past' and 'future' of the 'light cone' join, whereas the machine gets placed into 'elsewhere,' as it becomes enclosed in the sphere). We also notably see this image with the exotic windmills of the future Eloi, who evidently construct them simply for the purpose of remembering the dead. In between we see it more subtly, with the daily sun forming a band in the sky (an image from Wells' novel) as the time machine begins its first journey forward; we see it suggested by the spokes of the bicycles of the future; we see it in the moon which breaks apart and then gradually over eons begins to form a ring around the earth; we even see it even in AI hologram, who is self-described as, 'photonic,' and appears only through or behind one of a number of glass panes (which collectively form something like a Fresnel lens). All of this well functions in contrast to the Morlock, who hide from the sun as they seek to retreat from every contingency, from every 'what if.' Not once but twice are we shown the moon in association with hero's first romance, but also, in a very different form, with his second. Especially memorable along these lines is the time machine's entrance into geological time, with musical score waxing strong, where we witness the formation of a ring-like natural arch of rock, as well as the cutting out of a canyon by a river, on the sides of which the Eloi will be found to erect their unique architecture for dwelling. How could the hero still, 'blame the poor bastard who tore the stone from the earth,' for simply having provided the fateful engagement ring for his fianc&eacute;? If anywhere, the blame could only now fall to the Morlock-like thief who emerged at night from the bushes in Central Park, wearing his bowler hat. There was also some interesting dialogue in the deleted scene, where the time traveler explains to his students about 'differentials' being needed to overcome 'stagnation.'<br /><br />Yet all of this is still to wasted opportunity. The film does compare the time traveler with the Morlock insofar as, faced with loss, he wanted to retreat from contingency. A fine theme, as far as it goes, but nothing is really done with it.  The film does seem to have some kind of backhanded recognition that human beings are more than machines. There is also a fairly serious subtext dealing with irreplaceable loss and taking responsibility for the future. But here the movie is unable to take itself seriously, and the themes are not developed. In a way, they are even contradicted. It is eventually explained to the time traveler that his machine didn't quite work as he wished because precisely his motive was too personal (read, tragedy). What then is it to go 'too far?' Is the answer like the joke about which is worse, ignorance or apathy: 'I don't know and I don't care'---?  On this level the movie cannot be taken seriously. Its critique of technology is even 1950ish. At best, a sci-fi companion to 'The Emerald Forest.' At worst, it's a Godzilla on Gilligan's Island. Great grandson Simon Wells did a reasonable job directing it; too bad he didn't have the opportunity to direct a serious attempt to put the classic novel to film. I don't mean to say, however, that he therefore has something to be ashamed of; H.G. himself apparently had some role in the Hollywood version of 'The Invisible Man'--which was fairly comic--and this version of 'The Time Machine,' has an effective share of humor, also.  It also just happens to have some serious plot flaws, not limited to an occasional bizarre gaffe which could be easily extracted from the story without changing it (like the gaffe that his time machine, which was intended only to go back in time several years, just happens to have an elaborately constructed instrument panel, obviously mechanical and built with precise tolerances, able to display, to the day, a journey 800,000 years into the future).<br /><br />The high point was good special effects and music, though Guy Pearce and Samantha Mumba give memorable performances. For the Morlocks, Jeremy Irons is also memorable; for the rest of them, the combination of costumes, puppets and CGI was very well done and even (at times) seamless.  Mumba's real life younger brother was especially charming as an Eloi who befriends the time traveler.  The hokey portrayal of 2030 AD, however, insults the audience (a fusion powered computer which lasts 800,000 years?)--though the masses in NYC riding bicycles China style was a fun touch (while the time traveler was so fascinated, then sorely jaded, with an early 'horseless buggy' in 1899, upon his first stop in the future, he is confronted with neither cars nor horses)--and the brief flirtation with a woman unlocking her bike, commenting on the time machine, was an effective moment. What will people make of this watching it in 2030 plus? Though Orlando Jones holds his own (one of the great lines references the 'complete works of Martha Stewart' as a reading suggestion), it seems to me that the comic relief of the computer AI hologram from said year is, in terms of sci-fi, somewhat of a rip off of Robbie the Robot from Forbidden Planet and/or Data from Star Trek (perhaps a cross between the two). On the other hand, the movie is also complete with cryptic islandific BN for the many moments when the audience is likely too bored to pay attention to the story. But there are better places to look for that. There is an attention to detail in the film that does suggest a serious effort (even the engagement ring was made of moonstone); perhaps the original screenplay was more elaborate, but simply wound up truncated, for one reason or another, by the time they finished the final edit. Maybe they thought the film was too long; maybe they realized it lacked coherence. Was it the moon that blew up or the screenplay?  But the trip wasn't necessary; a classic story with the same name was already available. It is said that the (yes, fantastic) prop of the time machine itself took a year to make; also a wasted opportunity is the total reliance on CGI for the time travel sequences, instead of using that year to also do some time-lapse photography. Yet the far greater wasted opportunity lay in wasting all the film's merits, from casting and direction, to acting as well as to cinematography, on a jellybean script.  In the novel, the time traveler was actually a recipient of flowers: &#34;two strange white flowers--shriveled now, and brown and flat and brittle--to witness that even when mind and strength are gone, gratitude and mutual tenderness still lived on in the heart of man.&#34;  Pearce and Mumba almost succeed to rescue the screenplay, but not quite.  Mumba was particularly memorable the way she motionlessly 'rolls her eyes' without batting an eye, as she responds with a dead-pan 'oh' to Guy Pearce's explanation as to how he arrived there, by traveling in time, immediately proceeding to describe him to the villagers simply as a 'wandering idiot' to protect him.  Pearce also does a good job in showing a gradual transformation in the character; but from wandering idiot to superhero, is just not enough to thicken the plot.<br /><br />What, do movie makers really think that audiences are just plain too stupid to appreciate the ideas of a classic, even if a mere 100 page, novel?<br /><br />BYOP (bring your own popcorn)<br /><br />Having said all of that, I do admit I really wanted to like this movie.  In a way, I do like it, just not as much as I wanted.  I also hold no grudges; it has even grown on me.  At home, the film is good for playing in the background while doing something else; good music, nice images, not too distracting, and a gentle reminder to accomplish something before eons pass away, including perhaps a modest tip of the hat to Erich Fromm's, 'To Have or To Be.'<br /><br />All that being said, I wish to say that Dreamworks has a pretty good batting average for producing decent entertainment.<br /><br />5+ especially for Dreamworks' computer generated but also hand drawn animation (having just the right balance): SPIRIT.<br /><br />***<br /><br />FWIW, some additional explanation and analysis of the plot:<br /><br />While the time traveler did not succeed to change the past as he wished, he did succeed to change the occasion of his fianc&eacute;'s demise, from mugging to auto accident.  This near miss, is important for the story, for it is the reason he decides to go into the future.  Of course, it is also the case that the mere change in autopsy, per se, evidently made no difference to him; one mishap is exchanged for another, two flukes beyond his control with the same bitter result.  So, perhaps we are supposed to imagine, he indeed made the time machine (again) anyway?  Or maybe he left a note to himself, to be opened in 1903 or something, to finish the machine, but not to bother to try to go back and save her, as he already tried and it's no use?  Or the note said, 'wait until you hear from you again,' that is, after I-you-we take my-our-your first trip into the future to decide how to go about it?  Or perhaps he does go into the past again--and again--only to then go into the far future, again and again?  Maybe the reason he decides to hightail out of the past and not stick around was precisely to avoid seeing the mess of an infinitely regressing dog pile that he had set in motion?  Perhaps we are even to imagine that out of all these journeys, only 'one of him' actually makes it as far as 800,000 years into the future, to keep things simple; perhaps the rest die (or gets arrested amid various stops ranging between 2031-2036), or something?  Fine.  We can skip all that.  What we see is the time traveler, nearly a million years later, waking up dazed.  He had called his colleagues 'dinosaurs' only to witness the automobiles, which he once admired so much, to suffer a dinosaur fate.  His masterstroke of the time machine only succeeded in having his fianc&eacute; die at the hands of this latter group of mechanical dinosaurs.  Retreating into the future, he then witnesses another accidental destruction, this time of the moon.  Retreating further, he sees a divided humanity with the more technologically adept engaged in cannibalism.  Though in some way rationalizing, the Morlock in the film will even explain the reason the human race began to prey on itself was for lack of resources, after they blew up the moon; he also blames the time traveler and what he stood for.  Exactly what did he stand for?<br /><br />Perhaps the screenwriter (in the spirit of Wells' socialism) also intended the albino uber-Morlock to be the counterpart to the Dean of Columbia who (in the deleted scene) advised Pearce to give up his already forming ideas of time travel and join something like his study, 'on the benefits of tobacco smoking' (a pressure to which Pearce would cave if only his fianc&eacute; had lived). Was the declaration of going 'too far' with technology, as he gazed on a shattered moon, simply supposed to mean that he realized he was dumb to rely on a time machine--and a virtual librarian & library of the future--even to get his answer as to why he can't change the past (instead of on his own paper & sewn bound logic books)?  Would the time traveler then represent the ivory tower intellectual that cares for nothing more than writing equations on a blackboard and bourgeois private romances?  Fine.  We can skip all that.  How would remedying these defects provide a remedy to any, let alone all, the accidents of history--or comedy of errors--the film depicts?  The mishaps simply upstage and cover the tracks of any more subtly conceived plot.  Even the mugging was fatal due to a gun going off accidentally.  So we could better say that the time traveler in this movie simply represents the accident prone first mate, of the shipwrecked 'Minnow,' on 'Gilligan's Island.'  Alas, poor Emma, she just couldn't catch a break about the flowers she's always asking for (any more than Ginger could get a decent acting job after she met Gilligan).  800,000 years later, Mara at least knows enough to look for flowers herself; refreshingly, she is also a pretty good doctor, linguist and archaeologist (Ginger likewise found a few hidden talents while on the island).  There is really no sense to be made of this film, except that, according to it, science and technology are just accidents waiting to happen.  We don't have to retreat from it; just don't expect too much from it.  As for this film, try as you might, you won't find anything more in it.  Understatement is not always the same thing as nuance.<br /><br />The Morlock's explanation, 'I am the inescapable result of you,' could be summarized even more simply, as a big bluff:  'Your caring about people only results in the grotesque, sociopathic cannibal you see before you.  So give it up and go home.'<br /><br />Then Gilligan says, 'what if...' stumbles and blows up his machine, and saves the day.o). On the other hand, the movie is also complete with cryptic islandific BN for the many moments when the audience is likely too bored to pay attention to the story. But there are better places to look for that. There is an attention to detail in the film that does suggest a serious effort (even the engagement ring was made of moonstone); perhaps the original screenplay was more elaborate, but simply wound up truncated, for one reason or another, by the time they finished the final edit. Maybe they thought the film was too long; maybe they realized it lacked coherence. Was it the moon that blew up or the screenplay?  But the trip wasn't necessary; a classic story with the same name was already available. It is said that the (yes, fantastic) prop of the time machine itself took a year to make; also a wasted opportunity is the total reliance on CGI for the time travel sequences, instead of using that year to also do some time-lapse photography. Yet the far greater wasted opportunity lay in wasting all the film's merits, from casting and direction, to acting as well as to cinematography, on a jellybean script.  In the novel, the time traveler was actually a recipient of flowers: &#34;two strange white flowers--shriveled now, and brown and flat and brittle--to witness that even when mind and strength are gone, gratitude and mutual tenderness still lived on in the heart of man.&#34;  Pearce and Mumba almost succeed to rescue the screenplay, but not quite.  Mumba was particularly memorable the way she motionlessly 'rolls her eyes' without batting an eye, as she responds with a dead-pan 'oh' to Guy Pearce's explanation as to how he arrived there, by traveling in time, immediately proceeding to describe him to the villagers simply as a 'wandering idiot' to protect him.  Pearce also does a good job in showing a gradual transformation in the character; but from wandering idiot to superhero, is just not enough to thicken the plot.    What, do movie makers really think that audiences are just plain too stupid to appreciate the ideas of a classic, even if a mere 100 page, novel?    BYOP (bring your own popcorn)  Having said all of that, I do admit I really wanted to like this movie.  In a way, I do like it, just not as much as I wanted.  I also hold no grudges; it has even grown on me.  At home, the film is good for playing in the background while doing something else; good music, nice images, not too distracting, and a gentle reminder to accomplish something before eons pass away, including perhaps a modest tip of the hat to Erich Fromm's, 'To Have or To Be.'  All that being said, I wish to say that Dreamworks has a pretty good batting average for producing decent entertainment.  5+ especially for Dreamworks' computer generated but also hand drawn animation (having just the right balance): SPIRIT.  ***  FWIW, some additional explanation and analysis of the plot:  While the time traveler did not succeed to change the past as he wished, he did succeed to change the occasion of his fianc√©'s demise, from mugging to auto accident. The mishaps simply upstage and cover the tracks of any more subtly conceived plot.  Even the mugging was fatal due to a gun going off accidentally.  So we could better say that the time traveler in this movie simply represents the accident prone first mate, of the shipwrecked 'Minnow,' on 'Gilligan's Island.'  Alas, poor Emma, she just couldn't catch a break about the flowers she's always asking for (any more than Ginger could get a decent acting job after she met Gilligan).  800,000 years later, Mara at least knows enough to look for flowers herself; refreshingly, she is also a pretty good doctor, linguist and archaeologist (Ginger likewise found a few hidden talents while on the island).  There is really no sense to be made of this film, except that, according to it, science and technology are just accidents waiting to happen.  We don't have to retreat from it; just don't expect too much from it.  As for this film, try as you might, you won't find anything more in it.  Understatement is not always the same thing as nuance.  The Morlock's explanation, 'I am the inescapable result of you,' could be summarized even more simply, as a big bluff:  'Your caring about people only results in the grotesque, sociopathic cannibal you see before you.  So give it up and go home.'    Then Gilligan says, 'what if...' stumbles and blows up his machine, and saves the day.
B00006L83N|5.0|My first impression of Symphony X was that they were another Dream Theater clone. I am taking back my initial incorrect impression and believe they are one of the current innovators of the progressive metal scene. This disc is stunning. Michael Romeo is a gifted guitarist and a killer songwriter. Russell Allen's vocals can change from calming to brutal in a heartbeat and his tone is fantastic. Michael Pinella is a very tasty keyboard player who plays the perfect riff or chord at the right time. Jason Rullo (drums) and Michael Lepond (bass) provide the intense lock-and-load rhythm section, albeit, I wish the bass was a little louder in the mix. Both Pinella, and Lepond share some of the songwriting duties and Allen writes a good portion of the lyrics. <br /> <br />Most of the songs are heavy with lots of distorted guitar crunch but there are calmer moments, for example, parts of the twenty-four minute \\"The Odyssey\\" are classically influenced with beautiful orchestrated arrangements. There is not one clunker on the disc and is extremely recommended for fans of this style of music. <br />
B000ESSTKG|5.0|i got both violator and music for the masses last night and they are well worth the 22.99 asking price.  as the gentleman below mentioned, the sound quality is incredibly improved. this won't matter much to the average fan, but to mode-geeks like me, it's a godsend.  i won't go into the details of the album, because if you already own music for the masses, you already know what a great album it is.<br /><br />the documentary included is great.  as with the violator album, it's great to hear david bascombe, the album's producer, talk about the the making of the album.  the creative process has always fascinated me and getting a behind-the-scenes look at 'masses' is a treat.  to hear dave bascombe say the intro to 'never let me down again' was a 'happy accident' was a treat. it was also great to see how 'masses' made depeche mode one of the biggest acts in the world.  it's not every band, you know, that can sell 70,000 seats at the rose bowl. as with 'violator,' you'll get plenty of interviews with the band, the most impressive of which, in my opinion, is the interview with alan wilder.  you can't help but be impressed with the man and wish he were still a part of the band.<br /><br />for life-long depeche mode fans, these reissues are fantastic. sure, they could've had a few more bells and whistles, but the audio is first-rate, the dvd is fantastic, and listening and watching will take you back to the time when depeche mode were the center of the known universe.

B000ESSTL0|5.0|violator can best be summed up with one word: vindication.  the worldwide phenomenon that was 'violator' was the culmination of years of critics slagging them off and little mainstreet success.  if you're looking at this webpage, you already know all about violator's brilliance, so i'll spare you the review.<br /><br />during my teenage years my world literally revolved around depeche mode. i had the subway posters, the t-shirts, the videos (i wore out my copy of 'the world we live in and live in hamburg).  the morning violator came out i went to school and left two used cds on the kitchen counter so my mom could take them to our local shop, crandall audio, and trade them in for 'violator.' when i got home i found it sitting on the kitchen table, ran downstars and spent the next 8 hours listening to it over and over and over.  so i can't even tell you how great it was to get home last night, pop in the bonus dvd, and watch the band themselves talk about the making of violator.  what a great, albeit short, documentary.<br /><br />highlights of the documentary: alan wilder. it was amazing to hear him talk about making violator. alan's role in the band has always been underappreciated.  alan is a bright, articulate, eloquent man, and hearing him talk about how he and flood took martin's demos and turned them into 'violator' was a thrill.  it was also a thrill to see the enigmatic floor on camera. for those interested in what producers do (i certainly am), it was incredible to hear flood talking about how he and alan sent the rest of the band away for a day while they completely reworked 'the world in my eyes' and 'enjoy the silence.' we also get interviews with daniel miller, who started this wonderful joyride. we also get interviews with francois kervorkian (who mixed violator), and even anton corbijn, who as you all know, directed all the videos of the era.  after watching the documentary, it's easy to see how much the band means not only to the band members, but the everyone else who works for them. they love the band, the music, everything about depeche mode. you'll also hear the band talking about the near-riot in l.a. at tower records.  amazing stuff.<br /><br />it was incredibly neat to see a press conference with the band in which alan wilder says that the salt lake city gig (which had been rained out at park city and was rescheduled for the next night downtown salt lake city) was the best concert of the tour. i was there, and it was incredible.<br /><br />i won't comment on what the gentleman below wrote about. i have no idea what SACD, or whatever it's called is about. what i do know is that when i compressed them as mp3s this morning, they sound great (much better than the original rip) on my headphones.  that, as well as the documentary and album bsides, make this a terrific reissue, a reissue that mode-a-philes like myself will listen to and watch fondly (and with no small amount of nostalgia).<br /><br B000BYA5GO|4.0|Yuri Orlov (well played by Nicolas Cage), Ukrainian immigrant kid in Brooklyn in the early `80s, casting about for a career, witnesses an assassination attempt on a local mafioso and thinks: Weapons. Everyone wants them, everyone needs them. From selling a single Uzi to a local hood, he progresses to buying up abandoned U.S. small arms overseas, to shipping every kind of munitions you can think of to every part of the globe. Then it's 1992 and the Soviet Union collapses, and ex-Soviet army officers in all the various republics begin selling off the weapons systems under their control in order to replace their lost paychecks -- several billions of dollars worth from the newly-independent Ukraine alone. Most of his buyers are African, especially the bloodthirsty dictator of Liberia and his cannibalistic son -- and the Orlov character, who's well aware of what his trade facilitates, has a number of perceptive and pungent things to say about the West's attitudes toward the multiple African genocides of the `90s. (There are a number of shocking scenes and camera shots that are definitely *not* for kids.) Meanwhile, Yuri has acquired a wife, a high-priced model, to whom he lies continually regarding his business, until the straight-arrow ATF agent (or maybe he's Interpol; it's not clear) who has been pursuing her husband for years clues her in. Finally, Yuri's extremely troubled younger brother is killed during a deal in Sierra Leone and it's an overlooked bullet in his body, shipped back to the States, that leads to Yuri's arrest. The climactic scene, in which Yuri explains to the agent exactly how and why no charges will ever be brought -- the government *needs* men like him, though they'll never admit it -- is like a bullet between the eyes. The world's largest arms dealer, in fact, lives in the White House, selling as many weapons in a day as Yuri does in a month. And the largest arms brokers in the world are the five permanent members of the UN Security Council. This is a deeply cynical film, but that doesn't make it wrong.is a deeply cynical film, but that doesn't make it wrong.

B00005JO20|5.0|I have to admit that despite the other lukewarm reviews here, that I really liked this film. This is the sort of movie I go to to basically veg out, enjoy the action and special effects, and forget the real world for a while. I usually don't have high expectations for films like this other than to be entertained for the eight bucks or so of my hard earned dollars that I'm plunking down. The special effects in these action blockbusters are so spectacular these days that the human actors almost play second fiddle to that, and unless the acting is just plain bad, I almost don't notice it anymore in movies like this. But my expectations were far exceeded by this film on both counts.<br /><br />Several writers have commented that the movie doesn't take the original film seriously, or that it looks more like a video game than a real movie (mixing dinosaurs and Jurassic Park, essentially, with the King Kong story), but my response to that is a resounding, so what? If you think of the movie as more in the vein of Jurassic Park and similar fun action movies you'll be more on the money than the viewers who see it as a less than dignified and artistically wanting remake of the much venerated original.<br /><br />I think there's room for both types of flicks--artistically serious as well as non-serious, fun-loving action films that admittedly might not be much more than special effects romps. But they're still the most enjoyable sort of mindless, movie going fun. :-) If I want the other sort, I can always watch \\"Citizen Kane\\" and boost my movie I.Q. a few points that way.<br /><br />At just under 180 minutes, it's a monster of a film itself worthy of a three-story high gorilla, and in a film that long, there are stretches where nothing much happens, action-wise, which is okay, as long as they don't drag out too far. In this movie, the first third takes place in Depression era New York, during which we're introduced to the main characters and preparations for the expedition are made. But although the film has a long ramp up to where the action finally starts, I can tell you that the rest is worth waiting for.<br /><br />But once the action starts, and at the risk of sounding hackneyed (sometimes the English language fails me, or perhaps I fail the English language), it's nothing less than awesome. The scene where the dinosaurs are stampeded by the raptors along a cliff and then through the jungle is nothing less than awe-inspiring and that's just one of several great action scenes. Once I saw that, I was hooked and was on the edge of my seat for the rest of the movie. And we haven't even gotten to the scene where King Kong is battling the T-Rex--in what has to be the championship fight between the two biggest, baddest heavyweights in history.<br /><br />I'm no expert myself, but I've heard fans of action movies say that the best action movie of all time is the second Aliens movie. I'm not savvy enough about the genre to really say, but I'll put this movie up there with the best of them. And finally, Jack Black turns in possibly his best performance ever and Naomi Watts, who I recently saw in David Lynch's Mulholland Drive, where she was great, turns in another fine performance here. Jackson has another winner here and I think the movie is one of the best of the year.film has a long ramp up to where the action finally starts, I can tell you that the rest is worth waiting for. B0002S94OS|3.0|LOG play their instruments skillfully and stick to the thrash metal template with jackhammering rhythms and several exotic scales, noises, and time changes thrown in for good measure.  Yet what mostly differentiates LOG from their thrash forebears is Randy Blythe's combination of throat-grunting and shrill singing/screaming that doesn't quite sound like anyone before him.  Put Phil Anselmo on vocals with the same lyrics as Blythe is singing, though, and you have Pantera.  The antisocial and angry themes are here spouted with the median metal venom.  I want something more than a thrash revival in my metal, considering that thrash never truly passed.  Sepultura are still out there and they're doing a better job than LOG at innovating thrash music, by letting world music, classical, and electronic music influences into their music.<br /><br />Then again, if you're up for the same sort of full-on assault of the senses that have typified thrash bands since Slayer and Exodus (whose guitarist, Alex Skolnick, makes a guest appearance on the title track), _Asheso of the Wake_ will certainly get your blood pumping and your head banging when you play it at full volume.  I guess there's something to be said for perfecting a template that has already been taken to high levels, but in the process of doing this, they certainly have come nowhere near the classics of the genre, like _Master of Puppets_.  It's just all-American evil music.  I'm gonna stick with my not-so-all-American metal like Orthrelm, Pelican, and Dillinger Escape Plan.

0609610570|3.0|My dogged desire to get through this book ruined the first half of a windsurfing vacation in Aruba.<br /><br />It's very, very dry going, and at the end one wonders what, if anything the authors really had to say.<br /><br />It sounds on the surface like cutting edge management practice. For instance Bossidy and Charan introduce the concept of \\"the social software of execution\\" as a key element for creating the framework for cultural change in the organization. They go on to elaborate, \\"A key component of software is what we call Social Operating Mechanisms\\". At this point I was on the edge of my chair, ready to absorb what was being teed up as an idea of potentially transformational impact. So what are Social Operating Mechanisms? The authors go on to explain, \\"These are formal or informal meetings, presentations, even memos or e-mail exchanges - anywhere that dialogue takes place\\".<br /><br />Wow - this is really deep stuff...<br /><br />One wonders why the authors don't simply refer to communication rather than Social Operating Mechanisms. And, as a separate matter, the lack of literacy is surprising. Since when, for example, are memos and e-mail exchanges places?<br /><br />Stripped of all of this, what the authors have to say is simple common sense that can be summarized as follows:<br /><br />* Successful companies have the important ability to get things done (or execute).<br /><br />* Good leadership (knowing people, setting clear goals, following through, etc.) is a prerequisite of execution.<br /><br />* Reward systems, communications, and feedback processes need to foster action and provide incentives for getting things done.<br /><br />* Some people are more capable than others are to get things done. These are the people that should be put in positions of authority in the organization.<br /><br />* Strategic plans need to reflect the real world and link to operational plans. They also need to be tested for feasibility in the context of the organization's capabilities.<br /><br />None of this is rocket science, that is until one begins to cloak it in management techno speak such as that described above.<br /><br />And one more thing. The editor should have had a \\"robust conversation\\" with the authors about their overuse of the word \\"robust\\". It's really annoying.cloak it in management techno speak such as that described above.    And one more thing. The editor should have had a \\"robust conversation\\" with the authors about their overuse of the word \\"robust\\". It's really annoying.
